—Can the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade indicate what the Australian Government's response is to the so-called Shamir plan for elections in the Israeli occupied territories? Does the Minister believe that such a proposal could be a first step in achieving an overall peace settlement in the Middle East and, in particular, in the context of holding the proposed international conference?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The proposals that were first outlined by Prime Minister Shamir during his visit to Washington in early April were the subject of Israeli Cabinet approval on 14 May. They provide for the election by Palestinians in the occupied territories of representatives to negotiate with Israel. At this stage not all the details associated with the proposal, including details on the election process, are available and a number of outstanding issues remain to be resolved. These issues include the participation of Palestinians from East Jerusalem, the withdrawal of the Israeli defence force from the territories or at least from the main urban centres during any election campaign, the possibility of international supervision and, in many ways most importantly, the implications of the proposal for the evolution of an independent Palestinian state.

ANSWER.PARA: Therefore, against that background, while the proposals are welcome, they appear to me to fall short of the broader approach which the Australian Government has made it clear we believe is an appropriate and necessary response to recent developments; that is to say, including Israeli dialogue with the Palestine Liberation Organisation (PLO), which would, under the present plan, be excluded from participation in the election process. However, it must be acknowledged, of course, that the proposals offer a possible basis for further exploration and may, indeed, prove to be a basis for a way forward. While the PLO and Palestinian notables in the occupied territories have rejected the Israeli proposal, they have not ruled out the principle of elections provided they are part of a comprehensive plan including the withdrawal of Israeli forces from the occupied territories.

The Australian Government's position is one of encouragement to all parties to the dispute to continue to take advantage of the opportunities which now exist for progress towards a settlement. We note in this respect Secretary of State Baker's remarks, widely reported this morning but made yesterday, in which he called on Israel to `lay aside once and for all the unrealistic vision of a greater Israel'. He also called upon Israelis to `reach out to Palestinians as neighbours who deserve political rights'. The Australian Government certainly continues to support the right of self-determination of the Palestinian people, including their right, if they so choose, to independence and an independent state, and supports the convening of an international conference as a means of resolving the Arab-Israeli dispute.

Let me acknowledge that all this occurs in the context of very serious continuing pressures on Israel in what continues to be an extraordinarily difficult situation for the Government and people of that country. That must never be forgotten or overlooked in responding to questions of this kind.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer as the Minister responsible for the Australian Bureau of Statistics. Given the emphasis that the Government has placed-with the full support of the Opposition-on making non-custodial parents responsible for the maintenance of their children, can the Minister explain why the proposed question on family income for the 1991 census includes every imaginable kind of income except maintenance payments received? Is there any reason for this? If not, does the Minister agree that this omission can significantly underestimate the real income position of sole parent families, especially if by census night the Government has finally enacted its promised legislation for maintenance to be paid by formula? Will the Minister take action to see that all forms of income are included in the census so that a true picture of the economic welfare of sole parent families is available?

—I do not know whether the point that Senator Patterson has raised was ever explicitly considered by the Australian Statistician. To the best of my knowledge, it certainly was never addressed in submissions that went before Cabinet. It is always a matter of judgment as to how many questions ought to be included on the census form. I have forgotten how many we did settle for this year, but the recommendation for the preferred number, which I think came from the Statistician himself, was accepted. The more questions there are, the more expensive the census becomes. It is not trivial. If I remember correctly, adding just one extra question costs about an extra half a million dollars or $1m. It also makes the processing more complicated. It is a matter of judgment as to where to draw the line on the number of questions and the amount of detail required. However, I do take the point that is made in the question; that is, if maintenance payments received are not recorded on the census form, it could distort the true income positions of quite a significant number of households. I will take the matter up with the Treasurer, who I trust will take it up with the Statistician. It may well be a bit late to make any changes.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs aware of the details of the case of Mr Jim Stones, a Vietnam veteran rendered quadriplegic in Vietnam almost 20 years ago and now discovered to have been overpaid by $12,136 in the period during which he has been paid a totally and permanently incapacitated (TPI) pension? Is it the case that Mr Stones was overpaid because of an administrative error in the Department of Veterans' Affairs when his financial documents were submitted by his wife for assessment of his eligibility for pension? Is it the case that Mr Stones was actually entitled to a service pension as well as a TPI pension and superannuation from the Defence Force retirement benefits (DFRB) fund from the time of his return from Vietnam but was advised by the Department that he would be better off with only the superannuation and TPI pension? In view of the nature of this case and the fact that Mr Stones was overpaid because of an administrative error, as well as not being paid the full amount to which he was entitled for many years, a sum for which the Department will not reimburse Mr Stones, will the Minister reconsider his attitude to Mr Stone's current dilemma?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the answer to question No. 1 is yes. The Minister is aware of all details of Mr Jim Stones's case and of the overpayment of a service pension. This overpayment of the service pension is not related in any way to the veterans' special TPI rate pension.

ANSWER.PARA: The answer to question No. 2 is no. Mr Stones's claim was processed in accordance with departmental procedures. The overpayment occurred because it was stated on Mr Stones's application form that he was not in receipt of superannuation income and this led to the overpayment. Mr Stones's files contain brief references dated December 1970 and February 1976 to his being in receipt of a DFRB superannuation pension. This was some years before his application for a service pension was lodged in 1982. The systems, which have been in place for many years, did not allow for the degree of cross-checking which would have picked this up.

In answer to question No. 3, there is no record on the departmental files of an application for service pension being lodged before the application was received in September 1982, but an effort is being made to establish the precise detail of Mr Stones's dealings with the Department prior to 1982. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

As a result of early problems with the system, a review team has established the need for a range of data presentation improvements and these are now being implemented by the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) task force. Other ergonomic issues that needed to be addressed have been implemented. In the short term, there have been changes to the computer program, performance tuning of the radar head sensors and the way in which data is presented to the air traffic controllers. TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Has the Government directly approved the expenditure of some $2 1/2m for this relatively new system? Did the Minister, in a speech to the annual conference of the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association (APEA) in April this year, signal that the Federal Government would conduct a wide ranging review of crude oil excise to be completed by mid-1990? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that in April of this year, at the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association annual conference in Hobart, I announced that I would bring forward the review on crude oil excise foreshadowed in 1987 by the then Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Gareth Evans, and that we would commence the review in September this year rather than in June 1990. QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: LOGGING IN SOUTH-EASTERN NEW SOUTH WALES

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Resources. Does the Minister agree that the 1986 draft and final environmental impact statements by Harris-Daishowa and the supplementary document by the New South Wales Forestry Commission admitted to inadequate surveys of flora and fauna of the area? If so, is the Minister prepared to issue a renewal of the licence without adequate surveys being conducted? What period does the Minister now consider necessary for the conduct of adequate surveys and on whose advice? Further, how does the Minister explain his proposal to allow logging to proceed in parts of the National Estate described by the Australian Heritage Commission as having `very high conservation value' and `very high sensitivity' where logging would proceed contrary to the advice of the Australian Government Solicitor to the Department of Primary Industries and Energy? Lastly, can the Minister explain why another environmental impact statement (EIS) is currently being done by the New South Wales Forestry Commission for the Eden woodchip management area when one was completed last year? Could the new areas covered by the new EIS relieve the burden of logging in the 9 per cent of the National Estate the Minister has excluded from logging in his proposal to Mr Causley, the New South Wales Minister for Natural Resources?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the first part of the question, condition 5 (c) of the licence to export unprocessed wood issued to Harris-Daishowa by me requires that standing roundwoods shall be utilised for production of woodchips for export only when supplies of sawmill and logging residues available to the company are being utilised to the fullest possible extent. My Department has taken up this matter with the Forestry Commission of New South Wales and I understand that the company has complied with the terms and conditions of condition 5 of the licence.

ANSWER.PARA: In my presentation to Ian Causley, the Minister for Natural Resources in New South Wales, I proposed two substantive ways of supplementing the resource to Harris-Daishowa. I will not go into all the details here, but the first was a proposal along the lines of developing a plantation strategy upon which the woodchip industry could rely. The second was to hold further talks, should my plans be accepted by the New South Wales Government, for more efficient utilisation of small timber and for better use of sawmill residue as well as for looking at the scope of value adding to the manufacture processes resulting in a better utilisation of wood overall.

In relation to the second question, I have a vague recollection that Mr Justice Hemmings may have said something along the lines the honourable senator has inferred but I cannot confirm it absolutely. My colleague the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, advised me in January of this year that we ought to conduct a biological study looking at the floral and faunal values of the National Estate area in the south-eastern forests. My proposal to Ian Causley was that we do that with a balanced team of experts which would have as a reference panel the New South Wales Forestry Commission and the New South Wales National Parks and Wildlife Service. So far the New South Wales Government has not accepted that proposition, although I am waiting, as I said yesterday, for a written response to my proposals.

In relation to the honourable senator's third question, I have made a decision to provide for some forestry activity in 9 per cent of the National Estate forest in the south-east area. That forestry activity is not, I have to say, in conformity with the advice of the Australian Heritage Commission. I have had to make a decision based on an exhaustive examination of prudent and feasible alternatives. Yesterday in the Senate I tabled the written consideration of how I arrived at that decision under section 30 of the Heritage Act. I made the decision on those lines and on the fact that there are upwards of some 700 families in the south-east forests whose livelihood is directly affected by the timber industry. Their future is a consideration that has to be taken into account by a government that has to balance both the industry and environmental considerations and the fact that those families exist in an area which is not enjoying high levels of employment. In fact, the unemployment level in that area is twice the New South Wales average. On the basis of their needs and the industry's needs, I have decided to provide for cutting in, as I said, 9 per cent of the National Estate, leaving 91 per cent of the National Estate forests for the study that I referred to a moment ago.

In relation to the last part of the question, the EIS that is being conducted at the present time is being carried out by the New South Wales Forestry Commission. The one on which we are operating at the moment was needed to underpin the cutting plan for this year; the one being conducted will be needed to underpin the cutting plan for next year. The proposal that I have put to the New South Wales Government would enable us at the end of the period that I have proposed to have a complete environmental assessment of the south-east region to be able to select what areas of forest outside the National Estate can be considered for cutting. I would hope that at the end of the year that I have proposed we would then make a rational decision after giving consideration to all the competing weightings of interest and concern about the forest. That would be a logical and rational way of dealing with the matter. I hope that the New South Wales Government will now consider my proposal in greater detail, that it will not dismiss it superficially as it has but will respond in detail to the proposal. I believe that the community of that area wants a decision and wants this matter to be settled.

I am still waiting for a response from Senator Puplick. Yesterday, Senator Richardson and I both asked him to say whether he supports the New South Wales Government, whether he supports us or whether he has some other position. His silence on this matter is deafening. If silence be consent, I assume he supports the New South Wales Government. Because the policy of the Opposition in terms of minerals and energy is to abolish export controls in certain circumstances, I want to know whether Charles Blunt, if he proposes the abolition of export controls on woodchip exports, is going to stand up and argue for the retention of those export controls.

Does he agree or disagree with that proposition? —I really have nothing to add to what I said earlier, except to say that Senator Chaney keeps putting out these looney press releases about productivity, which clearly indicates that he does not understand what the concept means, and referring to nominal changes in wage rates as distinct from real unit labour costs. These things are put out every week, relating particularly to productivity. They just indicate that either Senator Chaney or the person who writes those press releases does not understand what productivity is about.
—You are starting to sound like Keating on Gittins.

—I think there is a lot to be said for Ross Gittins as a commentator, and the exchange between the Treasurer and Ross Gittins has been interesting. Senator Chaney is taking giant leaps, following his elevation to Deputy Leader, if he is starting to compare himself as an economic commentator with Ross Gittins. That is extraordinary. To talk about the great leap forward, Senator Chaney has made two in the last 10 days-Deputy Leader of the Opposition and comparing himself with Ross Gittins. That is absolutely ridiculous.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. Has the Minister read in the Australian a recent article which is headlined `Australia rides the fast track to a banana republic' and bylined by its economics writer, Robert Hadler, and in which Mr Hadler asserts that a bigger proportion of Australia's foreign debt is public sector debt than is the case for Brazil, Mexico or Argentina? Can the Minister advise the Senate whether the premise that Mr Hadler has based this article on is correct?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the article, and the most relevant section of it reads:

ANSWER.PARA: the ratio of private sector debt-

is much higher overseas than in Australia. In 1987, private-sector debt accounted for 75.5 per cent of total debt in Brazil, 86.2 per cent in Mexico and 85.8 per cent in Argentina. This highlights how overweight the public sector is in Australia.

I have asked my Department to check these facts. It appears that Mr Hadler's figures were based on data from external debt of developing countries world debt tables published by the World Bank. However, he misunderstood the tables because they refer to the source of the borrowings and not the borrower. In fact, Brazil's foreign debt of 75.5 per cent is borrowed from private sector sources in the rest of the world. That is where Mr Hadler misunderstood the table. He assumed that the borrowers were in the private sector instead of the lenders being in the private sector. The same applies to the other countries concerned. The figures are clearly not comparable with Australian Bureau of Statistics figures for the proportion of Australia's gross foreign debt which is held or owed by the private sector.

The World Bank tables do allow some comparison to be made. If we take the figures on that basis-this is publicly owed debt or publicly guaranteed debt as a proportion of gross domestic product-the Australian figure was 16 per cent in 1986. In the same year, Argentina's was nearly 66 per cent, Brazil's 41 per cent and Mexico's nearly 84 per cent. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the table which shows approximately 20 countries.
(a)* Estimated total external liabilities, including use of IMF credit.
(c)+ Public and publicly guaranteed long-term debt outstanding and disbursed.
Source: The World Bank, (1988) External Debt of Developing Countries World Debt Tables, Washington, p.xiv.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having clarified the facts, I do not want my remarks to be interpreted as saying that Australia does not have a foreign debt problem. I have said many times both inside and outside the Senate that it is perhaps the most serious single economic problem facing the nation.

—I understand that the Federal Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Hand, has held very extensive consultations with Mr Manzie of the Northern Territory Government in relation to the development of the legislation referred to in Senator Tambling's question. —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Reports to the Government over recent years indicate that neo-natal mortality for Aboriginal babies is up to five times that for non-Aboriginal babies born in Australia. What steps is the Government taking to reduce this quite unacceptably high rate so as to match it with the general neo-natal mortality rate in Australia, which is now one of the lowest in the world and which still masks the Aboriginal figures?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a supplementary answer to a question that Senator Maguire asked on 10 May.

ANSWER.PARA: On 10 May 1989 Senator Maguire asked me a question about Qantas safety precautions when flying in hostile areas. I undertook to get further information on this matter. I have been advised by Qantas that, when flying in areas of hostilities, the safety of the aircraft and passengers remains the Company's primary concern. paying close attention to ensuring that all requisite clearances are obtained for all operations, taking great care in evaluation of routings, undertaking regular security reviews of air routes, maintaining close contact with other traffic during flight, radar monitoring constantly utilising radio equipment to monitor international distress frequencies during flight, maintaining the aircraft transponder constantly in the ``on'' position, enabling Qantas to be identified as non-military traffic, ensuring crews are adequately briefed on potential areas of conflict.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a supplementary answer to a question asked yesterday by Senator Harradine.

ANSWER.PARA: In the Senate on 23 May, Senator Harradine asked a question relating to the use of UHF television channels in Tasmania.
The question covered a range of issues, most of which were well and truly covered in the answer which I provided.
However, I undertook to follow up with a supplementary answer to cover any outstanding points and now do so.

Firstly, let me reiterate that the Government has adopted the use of UHF channels for the provision of new and additional television services in Tasmania, principally so that those extra services can be introduced with a minimum of disruption to the reception of existing services. This cannot be achieved if the licensees are granted VHF channels in Hobart and Launceston.

Secondly, it is quite incorrect to suggest that UHF is unsuitable for use in Tasmania. It has been clearly demonstrated both here and overseas that UHF can provide clearer, better quality pictures that VHF.
It may well be true that additional translators will be required; in fact, the licensees should probably be providing additional translators for their existing VHF services.

I wish to assure senators, and the people of Tasmania, that both the Government and the Department of Transport and Communications will be doing what they can to ensure that the licensees provide all the translators required to deliver first class television reception to all the residents of Tasmania.

Finally, I make the point that whilst the UHF transmission equipment needed by licensees may well be more expensive than the VHF they would prefer, this is not the case for the UHF reception equipment required by viewers. In fact, UHF reception equipment is expected to last longer and be cheaper to maintain than the VHF equivalent.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —A week or so ago Senator Lewis asked me a question concerning allegations against Commander Lloyd Worthy made on the Page One program on television, put together by Chris Masters. I think it was put to Mr Worthy by Chris Masters that he-that is, Mr Worthy-could be a suspect for the murder of Assistant Commissioner Colin Winchester. I have some supplementary information which might be of interest to honourable senators.

ANSWER.PARA: As a consequence of these allegations Commander Worthy was transferred to other duties and an investigation was initiated into the allegations. The investigation was undertaken by Commander Allen and Detective Superintendent Lewington of the national Criminal Investigation Branch, Australian Federal Police (AFP) headquarters. In essence, the investigation by the AFP headquarters officers has confirmed that at the time Assistant Commissioner Winchester was murdered, Commander Worthy was at home with his wife and family. Commander Worthy has now returned to his former duties as Officer in Charge, ACT Region, Crime Division. That is a briefing provided to me by Deputy Commissioner John Johnson.

Commander Worthy was subject to an allegation which one can hardly imagine could be more damaging or destructive to the professional career or reputation of a police officer. The thought that he might even countenance, let alone to be involved in, the murder of Assistant Commissioner Winchester was of course extremely damaging to him. I have a very high regard for Chris Masters. I believe his type of journalism is important in a society such as ours, but I believe he would now concede that he has to reconsider the allegation that he made on that program. I would expect that he would want to remedy the situation in so far as it lies within his grasp to do so. TALK.START.PARA: —How does that qualify him to use your letterhead?

—I put out the press release under my own name, mentioning Dr Harry Recher's recent comments about his cooperation with the New South Wales Forestry Commission. There is no way in which Dr Recher ever had access to my letterhead, and nobody would. Senator Brownhill says that my involvement in the south-eastern forests is based less on fact than on fantasy. TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The need for immediate action to address the fundamental lack of competitiveness which underlies Australia's balance of payments and debt crisis.

This matter is not put forward this afternoon as a matter of public importance, which is perhaps the more normal device in this place. It is put forward as a matter of urgency because it is indeed a matter of urgency and we shall vote on it. It is matter of urgency that action be taken by the Government in the face of a deepening balance of payments deficit; in the face of massive growth in our foreign debt; in the face of growing foreign ownership of Australian land and other physical assets; in the face of a sharply increasing rate of inflation; in the face of a very high and rising level of interest rates; and finally, in the face of the developing signs of a recession later this year. Underlying all this is that fundamental lack of competitiveness which is referred to in the terms of this urgency motion.

It is remarkable to observe the change that has occurred in those in the Government who have had the chief responsibility for economic policy during the last two years. Very shortly after the last election, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) said-this was recalled on an Australian Broadcasting Corporation program by Andrew Olle last February-that the Government:
. . . is winning on inflation, it's winning on interest rates, it's winning on growth and it's winning on the most important thing of all the current account deficit and our external debt . . .

That statement was made by the Treasurer, Mr Keating, less than two years ago, just after the last election. What a change there has been in the public position of the Treasurer even in very recent days. Last week, on Tuesday 16 May 1989, Mr Keating was faced with yet another disastrous monthly balance of payments current account deficit. In that case it was for April, with an amount for that month only of $1,191m. On this day he faced a less than usually compliant media conference. I make that comment because Mr Keating has had the best run from the media in this country that I can remember any Treasurer having out of the 11 that I personally served, including Mr Keating. Mr Keating has begun to wear out the patience of even the media of this country. That is clearly because his own credibility has begun to fall disastrously in the eyes of the people who were previously prepared to accord him a great deal of credibility. What did Mr Keating say last Tuesday? In responding to a question he said:
. . . the problem is that even off this year's current account-
that is, this year's estimated current account deficit of nearly $17 billion-
we'll be looking at something like $2 billion worth of interest payments next year-
I think he meant interest payments and other payments, for example, property income payments, but I will let that pass-
just off this year's alone, so the trade accounts have got to run $2 billion faster just to stand still.

That is perfectly correct. The only surprising thing about the statement by the Treasurer last week was that he appeared to have discovered that fact for the first time. At a later point during that media conference Mr Keating referred again to that problem. He picked up in his rather magpie way another piece of economic jargon he had just heard no doubt from one of his officials-the concept of the net income deficit which appears in the balance of payments releases each month by the Statistician. He said:
That is simply the net deficit on our external payments . . . we make overseas on interest and other forms of property income against those we receive from overseas.
He said further:
. . . the net income deficit will be large this year, it's already-
that is, for the 10 months to April-
at 10.4 billion, it will be higher than that by year's end . . .
That is undoubtedly true. It will be $12 billion by the year's end. He went on:
. . . it will be higher next year . . . we're not going to be seeing because of that a massive decline in the current account deficit even for next year, even for next financial year.

Mr Keating recognised in that statement that even on that account alone, on account of having to pay interest on this year's deficit on the borrowings and the sales of assets which will result from this year's deficit financing, we will be up for another $2 billion next year.

I said in the Senate yesterday in the course of my remarks on the Appropriation Bills, and I will say it again, that this sort of thing reminds me of the experience that we have probably all had at one time in our lives of trying to chase our young children down an escalator. If we get into that situation we can, depending on how fleet of foot the children in question may be, catch them. The escalator is going up while they are going down and we are after them. We can actually catch them. We can go down faster than the escalator is going up. However if we keep on doing it for too long we run out of puff. We find that the escalator is going up faster than we can run down. That is exactly the situation which Australia is approaching under this Treasurer, who suddenly appears to have discovered that extraordinarily important fact, that extraordinarily important consequence of his policies in this place for the last six years.

Let me refer again to the remarkably expansive media conference held by the Treasurer on Tuesday of last week. He referred on that occasion to the tyranny of debt, picking up no doubt one of Geoffrey Blainey's phrases and adapting it. He said:

. . . this is the tyranny of the debt, you keep building up this net income deficit and Australia can't keep living on overseas savings, it just can't keep building up a stock of debt which it has to service and seeing a higher proportion of its trade receipts committed to that servicing.

I agree with the Treasurer. Verily a Daniel come to judgment. But where has this Treasurer been for the last six years that he did not discover this before this time, before our current account deficit on the balance of payments reached something like $16.5 billion to $17.5 billion this year? What could be more urgent, given the motion before the Senate today, than that tyranny of debt which the Treasurer himself referred to only eight days ago? We have a Treasurer who, while he is suddenly coming to his senses, is also starting to talk gobbledegook. I apologise to the Senate if it does not understand these words because I frankly find the greatest difficulty in understanding them. I am quoting them in order to illustrate the fact that we have a Treasurer who is no longer really on top of his portfolio. He has lost his grip. At a later point in his remarks, having been asked a question by one of our more perceptive journalists, the Treasurer, Paul Keating, said:

. . . there is a structural increase in the current account coming off the net income deficit as a permanent feature, there is some sort of implication in the question that once we get to some point of tightness it all sort of falls away, it doesn't all fall away, what falls away is the increment and the increment falls away as the merchandise trade deficit turns around and then reduces the current account deficit as it reduces the net income deficit or as the merchandise trade deficit overcomes the net income to reduce the current account deficit . . . that's the process which is being undertaken,
All I can say is that, if that is the process which is being undertaken, God help us. The Treasurer has lost his grip.

TALK.START.PARA: —Gilbert and Sullivan would have liked it.

—As Senator Bronwyn Bishop interpolates, Gilbert and Sullivan would have loved it. By contrast, let us have a bit of hard, plain and commonsense speaking about this matter from a respected figure in the economic policy arena-the Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia, Mr Bob Johnston, who was also speaking to a conference, the conference of the National Farmers Federation in this city last week, the day after the Treasurer spoke. I do not wish to attribute this motive to Mr Johnston but perhaps he felt he had to correct some of the impressions that the Treasurer may have created with the last remarks that I quoted for the Senate. Mr Johnston, on page 7 of the prepared text of his speech on the subject of debt, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Our overseas debt is rising at an increasing pace. The escalator is beginning to run faster than we can run.

On page 12 of his prepared text he drew attention to the fact that on the whole for almost two years now the Government has had a dream run on what the economists call the international terms of trade. The prices of our major export commodities have risen and have gone on rising until very recently, although they are showing some signs of weakness now. As a consequence we have been improving on that account alone. It is nothing to do with Government policies; just what is happening in the outside world. We have been in a situation which is favourable to us to improve our balance of payments. Our international terms of trade rose by 9 per cent in 1987-88. It was originally estimated to rise by 9 1/2 per cent this year. In fact, it has risen by more than that-something like 14 per cent to this point. The Governor was drawing attention to the fact which concerns many people: that situation will not last forever. The Governor said:
There must be a significant downside risk to the continuation of growth at the pace of the past six years.
This, after all, is the man who is charged with the institutional responsibility for the care of the currency of this country in terms of the Reserve Bank Act. Mr Johnston went on to say:
These uncertainties make it more imperative-
a very strong word, implying urgency-

that we come to grips with our own current account situation as soon as possible. As I have mentioned, this involves (as a first step) getting the growth in demand back within the limits of our productive capacity. When we have done this, there will still be much to do . . . but our own task, at the Central Bank, is clear-to lend the weight of monetary policy to the task of slowing the economy to a sustainable pace of growth.

Mr Johnston also said by way of interpolation into his prepared text that `if we do not do it'-if we do not do the things that I quoted him as saying-`if we do nothing at all, we'll simply set the scene for a very brutal adjustment of the economy at the behest of market forces'. That is what this Government is heading this country towards at present. This is what the Governor of the Reserve Bank said.

In the light of that and the fact that we are debating a matter of urgency, who on the Government side is going to speak in this debate? Where is the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), the Minister representing the Treasurer? He is not listed on the speakers list. I do not wish in any way to denigrate the Leader of the Government, Senator Button, who will be leading for the Government but the Minister who ought to be res- ponding to this motion is the Minister representing the Treasurer. But where is he? Instead, we are to have a contribution from Senator Button. We are going to have a contribution from Senator Maguire. As a matter of fact, we have already heard from Senator Maguire this morning in the debate on the appropriations. He told us then what he would be saying this afternoon. I presume that he can write only one speech a day or that he can have somebody write only one speech a day.

But where is Senator Walsh? Senator Walsh is not in the chamber and he is not responding today because for nearly two years now he has been telling his colleagues that they have got it wrong and that they have not been doing enough. In September 1987, just after the 1987-88 Budget, Senator Walsh told a gathering of Labor lawyers in Perth that there were 200 adjectival programs which had neither equity nor any other rationale to support them and which could be cut out but that his colleagues could not face up to the task of cutting them out.

On the Face to Face television program in October last year the Minister had some more things to say which were referred to in a question in the Senate yesterday. I will not repeat those comments other than to say that at that time the Minister committed himself to the view that unless the balance of payments improved we would have a sharp fall in the Australian dollar, which we have now just had, and that when that occurred there would almost certainly be-I do not want to put too much in the Minister's mouth-a need for further action by this Government on its own excessive spending.

Of course, the Minister in question called on the Prime Minister earlier this year to tender his resignation, to tell the Prime Minister that he proposed to resign. He was talked out of it no doubt on the basis at that time that there was going to be a very early election and that he should not destabilise the Government by getting out just then. Where is the Minister this afternoon? He is not in sight. We had Senator Maguire this morning telling us that this afternoon he will be hopping in to the Fraser Government. When was that? I can hardly remember it.

TALK.START.PARA: —You ought to.

—I agree. To some degree it should be burnt on my soul. I understand that. Nevertheless, Senator Maguire will be speaking. We do not have the butcher; we have the block. We do not have the organ grinder; we have the monkey.

SPEECH.PARA: This morning Senator Maguire was trying to tell us about the sharp rise in unemployment which occurred in the last year of the Fraser Government, caused, he said, by that Government. Senator Maguire appears to have forgotten that that very sharp rise in unemployment which, as he quite rightly said, took the figure to 10.4 per cent of the work force, was caused by the wage explosion in 1981-82. Who was that initiated by? It was initiated by Senator Maguire's friends, Senator Button's friends-I will not say Senator Walsh's friends-and certainly Mr Paul Keating's friends in the Australian Council of Trade Unions. It was initiated particularly by Mr Laurie Carmichael of the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union (AMWU), by Mr John Halfpenny, then of the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union and now the Secretary to the Trades Hall in Victoria, and by Mr George Campbell, who is now the Secretary of the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union, in company and concert with those two well-known heroic figures of the accord, Mr Bill Kelty and Mr Simon Crean, who are now somewhat in the discard.

We know the reason for the large rise in unemployment in 1982-83. It was given to us by none other than Mr Paul Keating, the Treasurer, at the Hobart Labor Party conference. Pointing his finger accusingly at Mr George Campbell of the AMWU he said, `George, don't you talk to me about this. You've got 100,000 dead men around your neck'. It is a fact that some people in the trade union movement did learn something from that experience. If they had not, there would never have been the so-called accord which this Government has spent the last six years talking about.

That brings me back to the whole matter before us today-the balance of payments crisis and the debt crisis. In the very brief time available to me, let me say that just over two years ago today the Treasurer of this country spoke about the banana republic which was facing us if we did not do something to deal with our growing debt and balance of payments problem. At that time our balance of payments was $14.8 billion in deficit; this year it will be $16 1/2 billion or $17 billion in deficit. At that time our debt was about $75 billion; today it is $95 billion. When the figures are published for the end of March in about a week's time it will probably be well over $100 billion.

Can anybody tell me that this is not a matter of urgency, that these matters are not to be dealt with urgently by this Government? What is the Government doing about it? The Government has its head in the sand unless, as the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) at the table has denied today, there is a review going on of wages policy and other government policies. I have to say that it is a matter of urgency that immediate action be taken to address this fundamental lack of competitiveness which underlies Australia's balance of payments and debt crisis.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Stone, the Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate, spoke for 20 minutes and at the nineteen- minute mark he said, `Let me get back to the subject'. In his urgency motion he referred to `the need for immediate action to address the fundamental lack of competitiveness which underlies Australia's balance of payments and debt crisis'. Sadly, Senator Stone said nothing about those issues at all. What we got was a recycled Treasury bureaucrat's speech about a number of issues larded, if I might say so, with Senator Stone's own demonology which he has used on a number of occasions in this place about what happened in 1982, the various people whom he thought were responsible and so on. The Government does not retreat from some of the issues implicit in the matter of urgency itself. But, with respect, it is insufficient to state the problem as a matter of urgency, as Senator Stone has done, and not address the issues, which are referred to as the underlying issues, relating to the balance of payments and debt crisis.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government will oppose the motion because it implies that the strategy that the Government has in place in relation to the reduction in both the current account deficit and the foreign debt and their return to more sustainable levels is inappropriate. It also implies that we should--

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you saying that it is appropriate?

—No, I said it implies that it is inappropriate. It also implies that we should immediately change tack and panic. But change tack and panic in what direction? One can read Senator Stone's speech in the Hansard tomorrow ad nauseam as many times as one likes and one will find no suggestion as to what directions we should take and with what speed the Government should do it. Neither of these responses-neither an immediate change in tack nor panic-is what is required. The Government's response to the current problems, to which the urgency motion refers, is to dampen the level of domestic demand. It is interesting that Senator Stone quoted Mr Bob Johnston of the Reserve Bank of Australia on a number of occasions. Mr Johnston's conclusion, which Senator Stone finally got to, was that growth in demand had to be reduced. Of course, the Government is entirely in agreement with that. Current policies are designed to reduce the growth in demand, and the various arms of economic policy are focused on these causes. The level of domestic demand in the economy and the need to improve the supply capacity are the two main causes of the current trade problem, and these are matters that the Government is addressing with various arms of economic policy.

SPEECH.PARA: This does not for a moment imply that we should give the knee-jerk response that the urgency motion seeks. It does not for a moment imply complacency on our part, or an unwillingness to adjust the mix of policies as conditions change. This Government has always been prepared to do that, and has done it throughout its period in office. I suppose that at Question Time yesterday I gave a formula answer to a question about when we were going to do this and when we were going to do that. It was a formula answer such as I have often given to questions about foreshadowed wage policy or foreshadowed policy in relation to exchange rates, interest rates or anything else. Ministers have been subjected to such questions over a long period. We have not been unwilling to adjust the mix of policies as conditions change. There was some evidence of that in the outcome of the Premiers Conference last week, indicating the Government's recognition that fiscal policy needs to be reined in a little not only in relation to grants to the States and States' borrowing capacity, but also in relation to the borrowing capacity of Commonwealth authorities. Both those matters were announced in the context of the Premiers Conference. Senator Stone was short on prescription, but one has to examine the view that the Opposition takes of this matter at a time when it is urging us to take immediate and precipitate action, a knee-jerk reaction--

TALK.START.PARA: —No, no.
—Yes, you are-it is in the wording of the motion.
—That is not precipitate or knee-jerk. You have had four years to think about it.
—If we have had years to think about it, the wording of the motion is most inelegant: `take immediate action to address--
—That is right: long overdue.
—Perhaps the honourable senator will give me a go for a moment.
—It sounds very pedantic.
—It may sound very pedantic to Senator Bishop, but if she listens for a moment--
—Just say you are going to take some action in a month's time.

—That is the interjection that I have been looking for: `Just say you are going to take some action in a month's time'. That is what this is all about: `We put up this urgency motion, and what we seek from the Government is the response that it is going to take some particular action in a month's time'.
—Like the action on the waterfront that you told us about last time.

—What a funny thing that the honourable senator has just spoken for 20 minutes without once referring to things, like the waterfront, that go to the fundamental lack of competitiveness underlying Australia's balance of payments and debt crisis. Not once did he touch on any of those issues of micro-economic policy.
—That is my job.

—Senator Chaney informs us that that is his job. So this debate is a movable feast. The motion signed by Senator Stone is not just for Stone, but for Stone plus Chaney-the new amorphous, movable feast that we now have on the Opposition side.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at some of the public statements made by the new Opposition leaders about some of these issues. Senator Stone quoted what the Treasurer had said two years ago, and Senator Walsh quoted Senator Stone's prediction of a recession, which did not happen. We could all play that game, but let us look at some more recent statements by Opposition members on issues that go to the question of underlying competitiveness. In March 1989 Dr Hewson, the new shadow Treasurer, speaking about tax policy, said:
The position is, we haven't really made up our mind about when we will announce it and how much we will announce.
On the same date Andrew Peacock, the new Leader, is reported as having said:

We have done the work. We have got our fiscal policy, including the tax package, the expenditure package and a target Budget surplus. We will announce it when we are ready, not when demanded to by an increasingly desperate Treasurer.
I do not want in any way to turn the tables on Senator Stone, or to turn the stone-if that is not unkind-but I repeat what Mr Peacock said six weeks ago:
We have done the work. We have got out fiscal policy, including the tax package, the expenditure package and a target Budget surplus.

The honourable senator comes in here today with an urgency motion telling us what the problem is, but he will not tell us that big secret, which the Australian people might be entitled to know. According to his new Leader, somebody has done the work, got the fiscal policy, got the tax package, got the expenditure package, and a target Budget surplus. On 17 August last year-the last occasion, I think on which he referred to tax policy-the then shadow Treasurer, now Leader of the Opposition, said:
I can give an undertaking, as you will see when we release our tax policy, to give significant tax cuts.

Now he is mumbling around the country about real tax cuts, as distinct from the Labor Party's tax cuts. He is hinting at real tax cuts which could be introduced if his Party were in power. As the Opposition always does, he is saying two things at the same time. I acknowledge that, quoting Bob Johnston, Senator Stone has said that we have to dampen demand considerably, or at least slacken the growth in demand. The Opposition is saying that the Government is not doing anything about living standards but that it-the Opposition-would do both things at once. It says that it would improve living standards. In the course of his remarks Senator Stone said-or at least implied-that the Opposition would do something about the things that Bob Johnston talked about. That is a Houdini-like solution. If the Opposition is going to launch urgency motions of this kind, it will have to make up its mind about some of those things.

In respect of fiscal policy, taxation policy, and so on, the Opposition, concerned that this is a matter of urgency for the whole Australian community, for the Australian people and for the Senate, is keeping as a deep secret what it would do in the circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are the Government. We would like some answers.

—I understand that we are the Government. We have been the Government for six years, and we intend to remain in that position. We are not going to be rushed into the sorts of knee-jerk responses that this urgency motion implies. Its very wording suggests some hidden solution. It is indeed hidden from us. Bearing in mind the remarks that have been made here in the last day or two, we would have thought that Senator Stone would share that secret with the Australian community. Of course, the real point of the Opposition motion is to imply that nothing is being done to increase the level of competitiveness in the Australian economy. I rely on the words of the motion, not on the speech made by Senator Stone because that was nonsense.
—You are under stress.
—Senator Hill suggests I am under stress.
—You ought to be under stress with the economy the way it is.
—Senator Hill is prepared to diagnose me but not the economy. I thank him for his kind thoughts and if he can make any further suggestions I would welcome them.
—You confused Senator Burns with a madam.

—When people change seats it gets confusing. Being a member of the Liberal Party Senator Hill ought to know that better than anyone else. Australia's external account imbalance, as I have said in this chamber-Senator Stone wants to ignore this-is the result of decades of policy failure by conservative governments. They ran down industry and capital stock and did not take any of the hard decisions on the micro-economy. The issue of competitiveness has to do with the cost structure of the economy: the cost of labour, capital, transport, government regulation--
—Capital is nice and cheap at 18 per cent and 20 per cent.
—It is about as cheap as the honourable senator's point. The cost of capital, says Senator Chaney sarcastically, is cheap at 18.5 per cent. It was much dearer in 1982 at 22 per cent.
—No, it was not.
—Yes it was. In 1982 it was much dearer at 22 per cent.
—When your Government took over.
—Consider the world recession we had.
—So, we had a world recession in 1982-another great suggestion! The policy that Senator Stone has talked about relates to the need to reduce demand in the Australian economy.
—In March 1983 the small overdraft rate was 14 per cent--

—I am sorry to disappoint Senator Stone, but I was talking about 1982. The areas which I was talking about were the cost of labour, capital, transport, government regulation, taxation and charges. These are areas this Government has attacked and which suffered neglect for many years under conservative governments.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me take a minute to talk about the cost of government regulation in financial markets in respect of which this Government has made enormous strides. I refer to government regulation in the sugar and wheat industries which, even in 1989, cause the Opposition so much agony in reaching decisions. Senator Stone was in agony as he made his speech in the Senate, with all the conflicting pressures on him as a result of his chosen vehicle for his political launch in this place. Those problems of deregulation which were ignored by conservative governments over many years come back to haunt them when they are confronted with them, even in opposition: the question of company tax rates, which have been enormously reduced under this Government; government taxes and charges, which have been addressed on an ongoing basis--

TALK.START.PARA: —You still have a balance of payments deficit of $17 billion.

—I understand that, Senator. What the Opposition continues to do is to recycle the problem and avoid the issues as they appear in Senator Stone's motion regarding the underlying causes of this problem, in the same way as conservative governments for many years ignored the underlying issues relating to this question of international competitiveness. Senator Stone is a bit different from the rest of the Opposition, and therefore naughtier. I have been saying for years that the Opposition is again giving us the 1960s show. Senator Stone has put forward a motion which talks about the underlying issues of competitiveness but does not address them once; it merely states the problem. The Government is aware of the problem. It is adopting policies which the Opposition attacks day after day as affecting the living standards of Australians and being hard on home buyers. The Opposition attacks those policies every day but in his speech Senator Stone did not say boo about what the Opposition would do.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Stone's colleagues have made pronouncements about interest rates, fiscal policy and similar issues. Opposition leaders make vacuous statements to which I have referred in the course of my remarks, but Senator Stone said nothing about them. That is extremely disappointing. Forgive me if I chastise Senator Stone for naughtiness of that kind. One of the major issues relating to international competitiveness is labour market reform-the importance of award restructuring and reaching industrial agreements on specific projects.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—Senator Stone might laugh but the Opposition did nothing about those problems over many years. The culture that makes those problems difficult to deal with developed during the lengthy period of conservative government. I also refer to the importance of the wage-tax trade-off. In respect of transport let me mention two or three other issues which relate to what Senator Stone calls the fundamental lack of competitiveness underlying the balance of payments crisis: the two airlines agreement and the waterfront and coastal shipping. The Opposition is right to chase the Government about those issues; we have to do something about them. The Opposition is absolutely right to chase us about that. A third runway for Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport was first suggested by Sir Reg Ansett in 1968. With 18 years of conservative government still to go, nothing was done about it.
—If I recall correctly it was adopted by the previous Government in 1978.
—The previous Government did not do anything about it. What we have heard has not gone to the nub of the question. We are quite happy to address the problems.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The $1.2 billion current account deficit for April published last week means that Australia's annual external shortfall has blown out to over $16 billion. Obviously, this is a long way from the $9.5 billion forecast by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in the 1988-89 Budget Speech. These figures are alarming. They have led the Treasurer to announce the possibility of further interest rate rises so that small business, rural producers and home buyers will be hit again as the financial sector in general and banks in particular respond to the Treasurer's high interest rate approach. The bad balance of payments figures have also caused the Government to reconsider its fiscal policy.

SPEECH.PARA: In the last 12 months the Treasurer has assured us that there are no plans to implement further expenditure cuts because, to use his words, fiscal policy is `as tight as a drum'. We are now getting admissions of a possible need for further fiscal restraint. Surely that tight drum is in imminent danger of being torn apart, particularly when one contemplates how the Government may tighten fiscal policy. Will it take back the $2 billion in tax cuts generally given to Australian companies last year when the company tax rate was reduced from 49c in the dollar to 39c in the dollar? I think not, because this would offend the Government's corporate mates. The problem with company tax in Australia is not the rate but the fact that so many companies do not pay it. In many cases they do not pay it because they get a tax break if they contribute to our foreign debt. I will say a bit more about that later.

The Government may also tighten fiscal policy by increasing tax paid by taxpayers, introducing a consumption tax-which is enamoured by the President of the Liberal Party-or implementing further expenditure cuts in areas which represent a substantial proportion of government spending: areas such as education, health and social security. The Commonwealth Government can either do that directly or do it by shifting that restraint on to the States. Of course the exercise in this Parliament House last week was partly the latter approach. Either way, low income households and average income earners will have less access to education, less access to health and less access to social security. We will have more of what we saw the other night on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's television program Nobody's Children.

It was the Australian Labor Party that introduced measures to take away income support for low income earners and for young people-measures that were voted into operation with the support of the Liberal- National Party Opposition. Both the Hawke Government and the Liberal-National Party alternative would do the same things but of course provide different window dressing to explain them to the public. In this particular exercise the Opposition has explained the situation in terms of lack of competitiveness. When I heard Senator Stone's address I suspected that it was simply another excuse for a bit of union bashing, as though Australian workers were the ones who determined the price and the quality of our export and import replacement goods and services.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who else does?

—Let us be clear about the situation. For example, Japanese workers get paid more than Australian workers. Maybe we should look at Australian management to find the problems, particularly those managers who blame absolutely everything on the workers. The unions do not happen to be responsible for the design of our goods and products or for their marketing either here or overseas. At least the workers have taken a decline in real wages over the life of the Hawke Government. That has not been the case with management.

SPEECH.PARA: Furthermore, this whole notion of international competitiveness makes sense only in theory. Let us look at this notion of competitiveness. One is not competitive in any sense of the term by definition if one does not sell goods against someone else who is selling those goods. That is not our problem. In fact, Australian industries are very competitive on a level playing field. Senator Chaney at least ought to know that. It is not our lack of competitiveness; it is the fact that we have a deficit on our trade account-that is, we are selling overseas less than we import. One can be highly competitive in that context and still not make the figures add up. Senator Chaney shakes his head in opposition to that proposition. Of course, he is not taking into account the incredible anti-competitive practices of the European Community and of our so-called special friend and ally the United States. We have very competitive resource industries and primary production industries, which are the mainstay of our exports.

In any case, the concentration on these matters misses an extremely important point that is too often overlooked, when the Hawke Labor Government, the Liberal Party and the National Party all discuss these matters: that is, we have a current account deficit because this country is spending more than it earns. But, as has been pointed out by Professor Pitchford, professor of economics at the Australian National University, excess spending is unusual for private households taken as a whole. He has also pointed out, and it is true, that the Government sector is a net lender, not a borrower. Of course, that leaves the private sector companies. But these companies borrow to expand. Each individual borrowing is supposed to be vetted and assessed by the financial sector against the capacity of the borrowing company to produce goods or services. In other words, an assessment is made of whether it is worth while and whether that company can repay the debt that it is entering into. So when the financial sector says we should worry about the current account, it is really saying we should worry about the finance and banking sector's ability to do the job of assessment. The debt problem then, to put it in terms of the matter of urgency, is a problem about companies and their activities. Professor Pitchford put it rather well when he said:
I'd like the Government to tell me precisely why they are worried about that-
that is, the current account deficit-

Do they feel that firms have too easy an access to debt and to overseas debt in particular, and you know, that raises the case, the issue as to why they deregulated financial markets anyway because of course, that made it easier for private firms to get hold of overseas debts. So the two things seem to be inconsistent, a concern about the current account deficit and a deregulation of the financial markets . . .

But, of course, the Liberal Party Opposition will pursue the deregulation of financial markets and remove from the Government any ability to engage in any activity in this area. The logical implication of the Government's position is that it should look at debt appraisal, it should look at the creation of debt in the private sector, if it is really worried about the current account. There is substantial evidence to support Professor Pitchford's view. I quote from an article in the Australian Financial Review of 19 May which puts it quite well:

Only 40 per cent of the current account deficit is accounted for by the economy's trade deficit on goods and services. The remaining 60 per cent-or $10 billion-is taken up by Australia's deficit on income and net transfers.
This largely reflects interest payments totalling $9.7 billion in 1988 on Australia's $121 billion gross foreign debt.

The economy is now trapped by a vicious cycle of debt accumulation. As the foreign debt has ballooned, the Interest Bill has become a driving force behind the worsening current account deficit-which then adds to the foreign debt and, in turn, to the debt-servicing Bill.

The alternative course of action to borrowing more, the course that is being suggested by the Opposition, is to sell off more of Australia's assets overseas. While this may look like a better solution to the immediate problem, in the long term it converts our foreign debt problem into a foreign ownership problem. Instead of increasing interest payments acting as a drain on our balance of payments, we will have increasing payments on rents and dividends to foreign owners of Australian assets. Of course, the Labor Party and the Liberal Party have formed an alliance to encourage more foreign investment and have kept Australians in the dark as to the extent of that foreign ownership in this country. Indeed, even in this place in March this year they combined to defeat the Australian Democrats' legislation to establish a register of foreign ownership and also voted against our amendment to the Foreign Takeovers Act which would have removed the $3m threshold below which approval does not have to be sought from the Foreign Investment Review Board for foreign purchases of rural properties, farms, et cetera.

So we now have the incredible situation where both the Government and the Opposition agree to sell off Australia, having conspired in the first place to give us a foreign debt of banana republic proportions. They go on attacking each other about who can go further in the effort to placate foreign financiers and domestic banks by deregulation, privatisation, cutting expenditure, cutting into the living standards of ordinary Australian workers and giving more and bigger tax concessions to big business. They ignore the real problem of who is responsible for the balance of payments blow-out and our foreign debt burden because the truth would hurt. At the end of last year, the private sector was responsible for 53.23 per cent of our foreign debt but ordinary Australians have to suffer because of that. At that stage, Australia's six largest corporate borrowers between them owed $26 billion or 23 per cent of Australia's gross foreign debt. Six firms owed 23 per cent of our foreign debt.

The Labor Party, the Liberal Party and the National Party have exercised their options in this country to sweep those facts under the carpet. There is absolutely no doubt that history will certainly judge them harshly for this blinkered, petty politicking, for being wrong in their prescriptions and for pandering to big business interests and international financiers rather than for doing the job for which they were elected, that is, to represent the ordinary Australian in an ordinary job.
