TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating an urgency motion brought forward by Senator Stone, the Leader of the National Party of Australia, in these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for immediate action to address the fundamental lack of competitiveness which underlies Australia's balance of payments and debt crisis.

The motion has been brought forward by the Opposition because it is our view that Australia faces quite a perilous situation, and it is the duty of the Opposition to raise this matter both here and in the House of Representatives, drawing it again to the attention of the Government and urging appropriate action upon the Government. It is a little disappointing that the response of the Government in this place has been as careless-that is as good a word as any-as the response from Senator Button, who giggled and joked his way through a 20-minute response and simply challenged the Opposition to come up with its solution to Australia's evident problems. In the course of my speech I shall certainly touch on some of the matters that have been detailed by the Opposition as going to providing a permanent solution to the difficulties we face.

Let me begin by saying that, in the speech from the Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Macklin, which as usual was composed mainly of attacks on the Liberal Party with a few passing attacks on the Australian Labor Party, there was one important point with which I wish to agree. It is important to try to find some points of agreement at a time of what I believe is real national crisis, which is understood in the suburbs, with the 18 per cent interest rates, the 16 to 16 1/2 per cent housing interest rates and the general pressure of living standards, all of which are part of the pattern that is tied up with our growing international indebtedness and declining living standards.

Senator Macklin referred to the vicious cycle of debt accumulation and servicing. Senator Stone pointed out in his contribution to the debate that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has admitted that, just to stand still next year, we will have to find an extra $2 billion-just to meet the additional costs of the increased indebtedness that Australia has incurred this year. So a problem which is already enormous is compounding, and it demands immediate action from the Government and not the sort of buffoonery that we had from the Leader of the Government in this place a few moments ago.

We have had a number of descriptions from people across the political spectrum and some non-political people who accurately get to the core of Australia's difficulties. In the interests of trying to get some bipartisan analysis, let me begin with what the Treasurer had to say. In a lengthy interview recorded in the Sydney Morning Herald on 8 April he said:
There is really only one message that can be drawn from our current circumstances . . . It is, simply, that our current account deficit is too high because we are spending more than we can produce.

The lesson to be drawn from that is that Australia faces two options: it must either reduce spending or produce more, or it must have some combination of the two. A reduction in spending is very easy to talk about. What it means is a further reduction in our standard of living at a time when most Australians feel that their standard of living has already been very heavily squeezed. The only attractive option, the only alternative that the Australian people would wish to see us embracing, is the second alternative-that we look to producing more in Australia so that we can afford both to pay off our debts and to improve our living standards. A great deal of publicity has been given to the prescription on this matter by the Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia, Mr R. A. Johnston, who, in the final weeks before his retirement, expressed himself in these terms:

What is the matter with the Australian economy? Some would say that we live in the `State of Self-Indulgence'. In the present financial year, total spending is growing at about twice the rate at which GDP is growing. Imports and debt service commitments are outstripping exports and other current receipts. Our overseas debt is rising at an increasing pace.

In other words, he describes the matter in the same terms as the Opposition has described it and as Mr Keating, in rare moments of honesty, has described it. In the same speech, Mr Johnston went on to say:
Tight monetary policy will ultimately slow the economy.
That is the prescription that the Government is following at the moment-shoving up interest rates on householders, small business and everybody else who has to borrow money. Mr Johnston continued:

But slowing the economy is not an end in itself. It will only provide conditions in which Australia can get on with constructive policies to improve the balance of payments. This highlights the urgency of shifting resources into export and import-competing industries and improving productivity and cost performance.

Again, that all sounds like just so much economics, but the simple, understandable point that the Government has refused to acknowledge and has refused to act upon is that both Mr Keating and the Governor of the Reserve Bank are giving the same message-not the sort of message of the populist sort of nonsense that I believe was a good deal of what Senator Macklin had to say, but the simple message that, unless we improve our productivity and performance as a country, we will not solve these pressing, dramatic and difficult problems.

Again we had some badinage from Senator Button during Question Time. I suppose his basic honesty prevents his answering questions properly in this place, so he indulges in jokes, quips and smart alec remarks to avoid having to answer questions. In the course of his badinage, he was very struck that I should dare to compare his abuse of me with the Treasurer's abuse of Ross Gittins of the Sydney Morning Herald. Let me deal with what Mr Gittins said in the Sydney Morning Herald, in an article on the issue of productivity, the matter which the Opposition has brought before the Senate this afternoon-this basic lack of competitiveness and the need to improve our productivity. In this article, which was quite critical of the Opposition, Mr Gittins said:

. . . the Opposition is right: we must raise our productivity-and it's a pity to see Paul Keating getting so defensive on the subject. Higher productivity is central to our efforts to achieve a sustained improvement in living standards and, of more pressing importance, higher productivity is a critical ingredient in solving our balance-of-payments crisis.

Mr Gittins was saying to the Australian people through this newspaper article that, if we wish to do something about Australian living standards and about our pressing international debt, we must lift our productivity. At the end of his article he said:
The way to achieve this . . . is to keep going down the micro-reform route: identify the industries where productivity is lowest, then fix'em and fix'em good.

That is pretty plain, sensible, unvarnished and understandable advice from an economist-find the areas where productivity is lowest or `identify the industries where productivity is lowest, then fix'em and fix'em good'. We had a challenge from the Leader of the Government in the Senate, who said, `What would you in opposition do?'. I remind the Senate that, in the House of Representatives, John Howard, in responding to the April statement, tabled a whole lot of papers which set out what we would do. They set out what we would do about coastal shipping where there was a $300m-plus loss to the Australian people in waste and inefficiency; about reforming the waterfront, where there is $800m worth of waste-and this is the specific area I wish to address; and about contracting out government services to give people better services at lower cost.

Let me make a very serious offer to the Government. It is an offer which I made publicly in a press release earlier today. I offered the Government the support and assistance of the Opposition with respect to reform of the waterfront. The Government has a report from the Inter-State Commission which says that over $600m can be saved for Australia by reforming the waterfront in ways set out in that report. I say to the Government and to the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, who is at the table reading his newspaper and, no doubt, thinking of higher things, that if it wants to reform the waterfront-and it must be done if we are going to start solving these problems; it is just one of the areas that must be fixed-we will cooperate with it. We will help get the legislation through the Parliament. The Government will get bipartisan support for the reforms which are set out in the Inter-State Commission. We make that offer to break the impasse which it is now quite obvious the Government has fallen into.

We have a government which is paralysed because it cannot come to grips with the fact that, as we were told by the waterfront unions just two days ago, the unions will never budge on the issues which have been identified by the Inter-State Commission-withdrawal of coverage from small ports and container depots; the inclusion of automatic stand down provisions in awards; compulsory redundancy; contracting out of work; and the use of casuals. In other words, we have a situation where there is notorious waste which is costing Australians dear. In terms of debt and reduced living standards it is costing them $600m to be gained in this area alone.

TALK.START.PARA: —A year.

—Yes, a year; and we have a Government which is paralysed. The Opposition says to the Government: we identify this as an area of national interest where we will stand four square with the Government if the Government is prepared to embrace meaningful reform. The Government could not get a more cooperative, more patriotically minded Opposition offer than that. What will we get from this Government? We will get temporisation and paralysis. I hope that that comment is proved to be incorrect over the next week. We will know by next week if the Government is prepared to grasp the nettle. I confirm in this debate what I have said outside the Parliament today: the coalition will assist in the passage of the legislation, including any necessary appropriations. It will commit a future coalition government to continued implementation of the waterfront plan, thus providing a climate of predictability and certainty for those involved in the industry. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the press release of today's date which I issued on that subject.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
COALITION OFFERS PARALYSED GOVERNMENT ITS SUPPORT FOR GENUINE REFORM OF THE WATERFRONT
It is now clear that the Government is paralysed on genuine reform of the waterfront.
To help break the impasse, the Coalition will offer bipartisan support to the Government if it is willing to implement a genuine program of reform on the waterfront.

The Coalition will assist in the passage of the legislation, including any necessary appropriations. It will also commit a future Coalition government to continued implementation of the waterfront plan, thus providing a climate of predictability and certainty for those involved in the industry.

However the Coalition's support is conditional on the Government adopting a plan that will lead to fundamental structural reform. The recommendations of the Inter-State Commission report provide a good basis for such a plan.
The Coalition is not happy with every aspect of the report-however it recognises that as a package it represents a framework for achieving real improvement on the waterfront.
In particular, it reflects the Coalition's emphasis on competition and a more enterprise based approach to employee relations.

Central to fundamental structural reform must be a move to full enterprise employment. In particular individual employers must be given the freedom to hire and fire employees that exists in industry generally. This should include access to compulsory redundancies as a last resort. It also means being free to hire supplementary labour without having to go through a ``pool''.

As recommended in the Inter-State Commission report, government contributions to fund redundancy payments should be paid progressively, and be made dependent on progress in implementing the waterfront plan on an enterprise basis. This should include the complete elimination of restrictive work practices and the introduction of multi-skilling.

The Inter-State Commission recommendations on union coverage and stand downs must also be implemented. These are not peripheral to reform-they form key elements in the Inter-State Commission's strategy of introducing greater competition and improving industrial relations.

Finally, there must be appropriate appointments made to the implementation authority. Members of the authority must be seen as independent of the interests involved in the industry, and as having a background that will ensure a proper appreciation of the need to improve efficiency and productivity.

We do not believe that these proposals can in any way be characterised as ``confrontationist''. Employees in the waterfront industry would continue to enjoy extremely generous pay and conditions by community standards. They would also be given the opportunity to take early retirement on terms far more favourable than are available to the rest of the community. Unions would continue to play a major role in the industry.
We are extremely concerned at comments by senior Government Ministers which suggest an inclination to back down on a number of crucial issues in the face of union pressure.

Inefficiencies on the waterfront are costing Australia over $800 million a year. The Coalition is committed to genuine reform of the waterfront. It is now up to the Government to show that it shares this commitment.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon we are debating a matter of urgency moved by Senator Stone on behalf of the Opposition which claims that the Australian economy has a fundamental lack of competitiveness and that there is an Australian balance of payments and debt crisis. In the motion Senator Stone calls for immediate action to deal with these problems. Of course we have a balance of payments problem in Australia. Nobody is pretending there is no such problem. The Government is not denying it, that is for sure. Of course we are concerned about the growth in Australia's external debt. The Government has taken action by way of a range of measures to deal with these problems that have been mentioned in the motion.

SPEECH.PARA: I oppose the motion which has been moved by Senator Stone. After all, there is nothing new about balance of payments problems in Australia-nothing new at all. Historically, Australia has always had balance of payments problems. Those problems have not just emerged under a Labor government in recent years. Australia has always had an overseas deficit except for a few years in the early post-war period. That deficit typically has been funded by a capital inflow because Australia is a developing country, a capital-scarce country.

Today I was reading a paper by perhaps Australia's greatest ever economist, Professor Trevor Swan, who recently passed away. In 1955, in a major article, Professor Swan diagnosed the balance of payments as the major constraint on growth in the Australian economy. He diagnosed it as the external constraint on economic growth in this country, the real constraint on expansion of our economy. That documentation was done in 1955, over 30 years ago, by Australia's greatest economist. It was a documentation of a balance of payments problem under a Liberal Government, not a Labor Government. This problem existed at the time under the Menzies Liberal Government.

There is nothing new at all about balance of payments problems in our nation. This motion is the biggest dollop of Opposition hypocrisy I have seen in the last several weeks in this Parliament. It is the biggest load of hypocrisy I have ever seen on economic questions in this place by this discredited Opposition, this disunited, disorganised rabble which claims to be Her Majesty's Opposition in this place.

Let us look at the Opposition's record on economic management when it was in government. Let us look at its record of destroying competitiveness in the Australian economy and bringing the Australian economy to its knees in 1982. Look at its record under Senator Stone, who was the first speaker in the debate, the person who initiated the debate. He was the architect of the economic policies of the previous coalition Government in Australia. Under that Government we had a massive wages blow-out, with huge double-digit increases in wage costs in Australia.

This morning I was looking at an economic report of the Parliamentary Library. In 1981-82 average weekly earnings grew by 14.6 per cent in this country under the coalition Government. Double-digit wage rises were followed by an increase of 11.4 per cent in 1982-83 under the coalition Government led by Mr Fraser and Mr Howard. Senator Stone was their chief economic adviser. These double-digit wage rises and double-digit cost increases for Australian industry made our industry less competitive overseas.

Look at the broad cost increases. Let us go beyond the wage rises that occurred under the Liberals. Look at the deflator for Australia's gross domestic product, the broadest inflation measure we can find. In 1981-82 there was an 11.6 per cent increase in costs in Australia, followed by 11.4 per cent in 1982-83. There was double-digit inflation under the Liberals. In fact, for the two financial years compounded, Australian costs rose by almost a quarter under the Liberal Government. Senator Stone, who will not cop the replies to his motion, has left the chamber again. When he was at the Treasury and pressing the economic buttons, costs rose by almost a quarter in two financial years-despite the avowed policy of the present Opposition, then in government, to fight inflation first. They were the avowed policies of the Opposition. Look at the record: Australian costs rose by almost a quarter in two financial years. That was the result.

Senator Stone has made great play today of the balance of payments problem. I have already put that into some historical perspective. The point I am making is that Australia has always had one. Senator Stone is now the Leader of the National Party in the Senate. So these points should be raised because, if he gets the chance again, presumably we will see the same policies put into operation. When Senator Stone was at the Treasury, Australia had a balance of payments deficit on current account of $9 billion in 1981-82. The reality was a deficit of $9 billion under the Liberals in their last full financial year in power. These things have to be kept in perspective. Senator Stone today glossed over the reality that economic variables must be seen in many cases in relative terms. They have to be related to the size of the economy.

—Contrary to this motion, the Hawke Government has acted on the economic matters contained in this motion. SPEECH.PARA: I would now like to look at some of the data on the growth of costs in the Australian economy-provided not by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) or by the Treasurer (Mr Keating), and certainly not by me, but by the Department of the Treasury. It is a very interesting concept. This material has been provided by the independent Treasury. It looks at the index of unit labour costs in the non-farm part of the Australian economy from 1973 to 1983. In that period the average indexed number of costs was 107, but by 1987-88, under Labor, the cost level had not gone up but had gone down-and gone down significantly. In the last financial year, 1987-88, the index had fallen from a figure of 107, before we came into power, to 98.5. So there has been a terrific reduction in unit labour costs of production under this Government, something that Senator Stone, when he was at the Treasury, was never able to achieve. When we read that advice which has been put forward by the independent Treasury-not by the Prime Minister or the Treasurer-we see that it says that by 1987-88 there had been a 9 per cent reduction in unit labour costs compared with 1982-83. I turn to broad cost measures in the economy. As I mentioned before, the broadest measure is the deflator for gross domestic product in the non-farm sector. Mrs Beard, a former union official who is married with two young children, said her general household bills have increased from $70 a week to $110 to $120 in the last year.

Let me refer to what the Governor of the Reserve Bank, Mr Johnston, on 17 May said when he addressed the National Farmers Federation. He said:

What is the matter with the Australian economy? Some would say that we live in the ``State of Self-Indulgence''. In the present financial year, total spending is growing at about twice the rate at which GDP is growing.

We say to the Government that it is time that it addressed these fundamental issues and brought competitiveness into this economy, so changing the situation so that this country can start to do something about meeting the enormous national debt which it is facing at present.

Our manufacturing industry, as we all know, was protected by high tariffs, quotas, and an overvalued Australian dollar. It was taking in its own washing. He said that we will try to overcome problems such as the invasion of foreign imports, lack of reliability and relative high prices. He said that this will not happen overnight. He does not act on behalf of the car industry on the Windsor Road or to tell people on television that he will do a deal for them, that he `will do it right for you' as Tony Packard says. Is it wrong to wean workers away from an inflationary reliance on ever-increasing wages? DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Report

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This major report is a significant indictment of the Government and its policies. If one looks at the report one sees an estimate by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission of at least 20,000 to 25,000 homeless children and young people across the country. We are prepared to provide economic support when a family breaks down, but not the support services which might have prevented the breakdown. We expect the family to take the lion's share of caring for its dependent members without providing the support necessary for it to do so.

This is a message that we have been attempting to bring home to the Government for a long time-that the problem is severe. That message is now being reinforced by this respected and independent body; furthermore, remedial action should lie in the area of family support.

. . . the evidence suggests that many low income people, especially families with children have to survive on insufficient nutrition, are unable to heat their homes in winter, are often unable to afford medication, and are denied most forms of recreation. The Government has not listened to that message. It has made promises to the Australian people which it has not kept. It is a critically important area and the Government stands condemned for its record in this area.

As well as economic issues, there are also great social issues involved. Child homelessness is not a new phenomenon; it has always been with us to some degree. But what is new in our society is its appearance on such a wide scale. The report indicates that between 20,000 and 25,000 children are now living on the streets, many of them following a life of crime, prostitution and drug addiction. That figure is almost certainly highly conservative. These children face a world of despair and uncertainty. It is an appalling indictment of the changes in our society over the past couple of decades or more and something about which we should all feel deeply troubled. I think the most important of the changes that have caused this problem are the dramatic changes to the family and the changes that have led to youth unemployment and support for some of the social dogmas and policies of the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s. These issues have been compounded very significantly by the policies of the Hawke Government. As Senator Hill said, the pledge by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in the 1987 election campaign that by the year 1990 no child will be living in poverty has been proved, by this report alone, to be a quite monstrous deception of those most in need in our community.

Two factors have led, I believe, to the problems that we face. One is the breakdown of the role of the family in our society and the role of parents in helping to bring up their children and make their children responsible as part of a family unit. This is part of the fundamental reason for the homelessness problem plus many of the other social problems that we now face. The second factor that is of the gravest concern to me is the policies of this Government which have led to a breakdown of the code of volunteerism in our society and the major role that can be played by voluntary associations. Until such time as we change the policies which have made them the poor relations in our community, we will continue to have the problems that this report so dramatically, sadly and compassionately highlights.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too want to add some words in support of this very important and timely report. I was prompted to do so by the words uttered by Senator Short, who preceded me in this debate. Earlier in his contribution to the debate Senator Short said that there is no one side singly responsible for the plight of homeless youth in Australia today. I accept that view. I commend Senator Short for showing a bipartisan attitude to a very grave human problem that besets the youth of Australia in our society today. It would be all too easy for us, as parliamentarians, to shed blame without examining the causes. One of the causes put forward for homeless youth in Australia today has been said to be family breakdown. Certainly that is one contributing factor, a very important contributing factor, but not the only one. If we are to address the problem of homeless children in Australia today we have to look behind the one glib simplistic answer. For that reason I was prompted to get up and commend the words of Senator Short in his excellent contribution here this afternoon.

SPEECH.PARA: I also commend an Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) program on this issue which was telecast in two parts last week. Unfortunately, on the first day, on Wednesday of last week, I was in a part of my electorate that does not have access to television. I did not see the first part but it is recorded and it will be looked at at a later time. I did see the second part. It was an excellent further contribution to the examination of a very difficult situation that we have in Australia today. That second part, the only part of the program that I did see, reinforces the view that I put forward earlier in my contribution-that there is no single cause of the problem of our homeless children.

I now turn to a negative note. At the conclusion of this program we had the unfortunate experience of a further ABC program on the same theme called Couchman. The program is hosted by an ABC commentator called Peter Couchman and at this time I remind the Senate that the ABC is costing each taxpayer 8c a day. At the very commencement of the program he said that nobody in Australia today is listening to the homeless youth. Just after he finished that sentence he introduced Mr Burdekin, saying that Mr Burdekin had been listening to homeless youth for 17 months. Despite that very poor start, the program just got worse and worse. Mr Couchman, who was supposed to be in charge of the program, lost a great deal of control of what could have been another valuable contribution. I think that people who watched both programs as well as the Couchman report might have ended up with a very negative view of this enormous problem that confronts us today.

It is a problem that has to be addressed. There is no question about it; it just has to be addressed. In attempting to address that problem it would be better if we could get some degree of bipartisan support from all political parties. Certainly there will be point-scoring in the debate on the way through but hopefully that political point-scoring will not overshadow that problem of some of our youth in Australia today. I certainly hope that is so and I am encouraged by the words of Senator Short in his earlier contribution to the debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report on homeless children has indeed shocked everybody. The Australian Democrats certainly join with Commissioner Brian Burdekin in expressing our deep concern over the issues that have been raised by this inquiry into child homelessness. As Senator Hill stated earlier, the news is not new to us. As long ago as last December, the Age reported on a report of the Australian Institute of Family Studies that:

SPEECH.PARA: Government policies to aid unsupported, homeless youths need overhauling because they have created confusion and failed to give adequate support . . .

I agree with Senator McKiernan that it is up to all of us to work together towards correctly putting an end to the dreadful situations highlighted in the report Our Homeless Children. Nonetheless, in doing that, we must look at the situation and what is provided. The article in the Age highlighted the fact that the programs of income support, training and homeless allowances do not appear to be working. It went on to say:

. . . recent policy developments placed the responsibility for young people firmly back on the family, leaving many homeless young people in a perilous state, while responsibilities were shuffled between departments.

That is not helpful to our homeless youth. When Commissioner Burdekin was questioned on his report, he pleaded with governments, the media and the bureaucracy not to let youth homelessness become just another issue. He stressed the enormity of the situation and pleaded that we should all recognise it. He said that if we cannot recognise this:
. . . we face the very real prospect of an already tragic problem becoming something virtually uncontrollable.
The report estimated that there are between 130,000 and 150,000 homeless Australians, of whom up to 70,000 are aged between 12 and 24 years. Mr Burdekin continued:
. . . the number of homeless would rise unless governments and the bureaucracy adopted a revolutionary solution to the problem.

Of all the recommendations in the report, Commissioner Burdekin highlighted the need for a task force which, although it may be composed of bureaucrats, would spend time talking to people on the ground. The issues that Commissioner Burdekin was referring to are highlighted in a horrendous article in today's West Australian, entitled `What is happening to our children?'. It reads:
The dreadful fantasy of the Clockwork Orange in which violent gangs turned on the society that spawned them, does not seem so fantastic these days.

Clearly, the danger is that we can look to greater violence on our streets unless we can solve the homelessness problem. Although the young muggers on the streets are not all homeless-and there is no doubt about that because some of them come from very good homes but still resort to violence-the homeless youths on the streets can also be drawn into those sorts of situations. Certainly, social conflict and violence within the home environment remains the major cause of young people leaving home, forcing them to fend for themselves on the streets.

The report of the National Inquiry into Homeless Children has been awaited with a lot of trepidation, and it is unfortunate that the findings are predictable. It is becoming increasingly obvious that the Federal Government has not been successful in its endeavours to eradicate child poverty, which is one of the major problems. It will not be until all levels of government and, indeed, all of us accept responsibility for the development of a comprehensive and effective youth program that the social difficulties created by child poverty and the subsequent homelessness can be resolved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to make a few comments on the report Our Homeless Children, which has become known as the Burdekin report. I welcome the report because it focuses the eye of the media on this matter. It certainly elevates it in the public debate, to make people aware that we have 25,000 homeless youths in the streets of Australia. This is everyone's responsibility. We cannot pass the buck. The aspect that I find hardest to accept is that we have presided over the emergence of a real subculture made up of a significant number of our children who have deliberately rejected the society that we have built for them.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important to differentiate between the youths who opt out and those who are homeless because of a family crisis, abuse or maltreatment. It is the child who is on the run because of the home environment that should be the first objective of our concern. Every government should be leading the way in breaking up the cycle of child abuse and homelessness with sound policies and programs, placing emphasis on the survival of the family. Non-government agencies have contributed a great deal through church and community initiatives. In Logan City, which is one of the more depressed areas in Brisbane, Boys Town has recently set up a crisis accommodation centre which provides professional and non-threatening help and reduces the workload of the police. There are also a number of homes in Brisbane run by local people who provide children in crisis with short term accommodation before referring them to another range of places. These people deserve tremendous support. I know there is such a group in Wynnum, where I live, which does a wonderful job.

I referred earlier to the difference between the majority that desperately need assistance and the small but growing percentage of homeless children who have made a deliberate choice to be homeless. This is not something that I feel comfortable in saying because it is an admission of failure on the part of all of us, but it would be worse to turn a blind eye, to set up preconceived ideas and stick to them, to find out only what could be coped with and ignore the rest. Some of our youths want to live in these conditions without responsibilities. No matter whether they are provided with hostels or other types of accommodation, they do not want to change from their particular lifestyle. They do not want to work and do not want to have work. They refuse to accept normal limits of their behaviour and they certainly do not tolerate discipline. They do not look after the accommodation and housing which is offered to them.

This subculture has influence and leadership over the real victims of homelessness, the abused and the mistreated, and sometimes exerts a distorting influence over research and media coverage. It serves no purpose except to enhance the image of the subculture heroes. As I mentioned before, the hardest thing to accept is that some of our youths deliberately choose to reject our society. A very real subculture has emerged which does not accept our offer of housing, foster families, work and life in the Australian mainstream.

In the short time remaining to me I say that I honestly believe that the only way to provide the best care for children is to support family policies that encourage the home, and acknowledge the family as the basic unit of society. If the family can hold together, we will not have children out on the streets. Every government has to be encouraged to produce policies that will support the family, policies that allow families to have homes without paying massive interest rates and taxation policies that allow people a decent form of living. Unless those policies are forthcoming from any government, we will have homeless children. We cannot develop policies that exert pressures on the family and make a home a battleground rather than a family situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report Our Homeless Children is one of the most serious reports to have come before the Parliament this year. It is quite timely that this report has been tabled when little more than six months remains for the fulfilment of the pledge made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on the eve of the 1987 election that no Australian child would be living in poverty by 1990. I was concerned that Senator McKiernan, the only senator on the Government side who has spoken on this matter, did not mention that promise and how, if the Government was serious, it was going to keep it. I do not necessarily blame this or any other government, which is the point that Senator Short and Senator McKiernan were addressing, for failing to eliminate poverty in two and a half years.

SPEECH.PARA: Australians have every right to blame a politician who makes such a commitment before an election and then tries to renege on it. That to me is the sin. The Prime Minister now says that there is no need for a child to be in poverty and that the problem of homeless youth is due to family breakdown. That was certainly not his story, his line or the method in his madness in making such a scandalous commitment prior to the last election. It really begs the question that the major contributing cause of family breakdown is economic pressure, to which the policies of this Labor Government contribute heavily.

The most optimistic estimate of the number of Australian children who will be living in poverty after the impact of the family package of this Government is, according to Brownlee and King, 260,800 people. Sadly, this is the pool from which so many homeless adolescents will be drawn. According to a report quoted by a major Western Australian voluntary welfare agency, Anglicare, there are 77,000 children in my State living below the poverty line. This could translate into a potential and actual problem of hundreds of teenagers leaving home.

Younger Australians remain major victims of unemployment, with 77,600 in the 15-19 age group seeking full time work last month. This unemployment rate of 14.3 per cent is a slight improvement upon the disastrous 21 per cent of only two years ago but is still more than double the overall unemployment rate of 6.2 per cent. This Government is wondering why there is so much homeless youth. It has only to look at its own disastrous results in finding employment for young people. High youth unemployment can mean family dislocation and youth poverty.

It is the conclusion of the Australian Institute of Family Studies that unemployed 16- and 17-year-olds are more likely to leave home than those who obtain work. An institute survey of unemployed teenagers in these circumstances showed that they receive a median income of $135 per week to be set against the July 1988 poverty line figure of $149 before housing costs. These were not street kids or substance abusers but young Australians caught in a situation of poverty. They need to spend 25 per cent of income even on subsidised accommodation and claim that `you don't cope, you struggle'. These figures do not point to the need for higher welfare payments but for more effective action to tackle the problems of joblessness and family breakdown when overall economic policy places the family under extreme strain. It is true that some children and adolescents from affluent circumstances suffer family breakdown and impairment and may become `voluntary' victims of homelessness and subsequent poverty. But, overwhelmingly, evidence suggests that economic pressure plays a big part in the divorce rate-4,600 a year in Western Australia-and that then causes young Australians to be raised in relative deprivation.

The actual cost of raising children, particularly teenagers, must be a very real factor in precipitating homelessness where relationships with parents and, more often, step-parents are impaired. The latest information from the Australian Institute of Family Studies shows that low income families really are very badly off in terms of the amount of support they get from welfare. The money they receive does not go anywhere near covering the costs. We have a problem with homeless youth and poverty not because this Government pays insufficient welfare but because the root causes of the problem-the breakdown of families and the pressure of housing costs and living costs-are not being met by the Government.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON EMPLOYMENT, EDUCATION AND TRAINING

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 10 May, on motion by Senator Aulich:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This important report from the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training has been widely publicised throughout the community and is beginning to be publicised in our schools and other youth organisations. There have been helpful responses by State education Ministers and already this is clearly a very successful report.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the best decisions made by the Senate Committee was to name the inquiry `active citizenship'. This is a positive concept; it is something that is of importance to every single Australian; and it is a matter that should have been addressed many years ago. There is a certain fragility in any democracy if the citizens of a country are not fully aware of their rights and are not fulfilling the potential for participation in all the decision making processes of the country. Australia should strengthen the foundations for democracy. One of the ways to do that is for the Commonwealth and State governments to take up the findings and recommendations of the Senate inquiry.

At the outset I would like to commend the professional support that was given to the Committee by various officers of this Parliament. I can only say that they went about their work with total professionalism. I commend Mr Derek Allan, the Secretary of the Committee, and the research staff who assisted us in every aspect of the conduct of the inquiry. They showed full professionalism in the normal pursuits of dealing with our reference, ensuring that interested bodies or potentially interested bodies around Australia were aware of our inquiry and were able to make submissions, organising the way we conducted our hearings throughout Australia and preparing the written report. They applied themselves with considerable imagination. We ensured that a discussion paper was produced before we had most of our hearings. We produced a large print edition of the report so that those with limited eyesight would have access to it. We ensured that a film and an audio tape of comments setting out main points of the report were made available throughout Australia. During the course of the inquiry we arranged for some of the hearings to be videotaped. This was the first time we had taken such a step. This inquiry has set new standards in terms of the way in which the Senate and its committees can communicate with the Australian public and ensure participation.

In the five minutes that remain, let me say something about some matters of the report that were of particular importance to me. It is important that Australians understand the politics of this country; its Constitution; the three levels of government; the nature of local, State and Federal government; the processes of the Parliament; the methods of election; and the detailed procedures of Australian democracy. They should have some knowledge of the long centuries of the Westminster tradition; the concepts of account- ability; and the nature of decision making, which is wider than government and parliament, and involves writers, the Public Service, the Press, political parties and so on. Not only is it necessary for greater information to be given to the Australian public on all these matters, but it should be available in a way that is not static but dynamic; not just an anatomy lesson of decision making in this country but one that has clear signposts to each individual's ability to be involved.

The knowledge of Australian citizenship should be an active knowledge. There should be no particular barriers to individuals taking up their interests and participating actively themselves. The curricula for teaching these matters in our schools have been too static and not dynamic enough. One of the reasons for this is that, as soon as one goes from a description of the anatomy of decision making in this country to one that is participatory, active and empowering to those involved in such courses, to some extent controversy arises.

Parents tend not to trust active teaching about political decision making in this country if they do not have full confidence in the actual views of the teacher. Yet to teach this actively and effectively requires commitment and involvement by those who are teaching or are responsible for courses. One cannot teach active decision making in Australia without some experience of activity. If it is taught in a bland, anatomical way, it will not inspire anyone to action. So there is a call or a need for considerable maturity on the part of those responsible for curricula in schools or at any level of learning given by public institutions. This maturity has sometimes been wanting and has led to controversy. I reinforce the finding of the inquiry that, nevertheless, we press ahead with encouragements to active citizenship through committed people with an active, empowering perspective but one which, of course, must have maturity, fairness and accountability so that this kind of controversy does not arise.

Let me also refer to the concept of youth parliaments. I believe that one activity that may lead young Australians to be eventually involved at the three levels of government in this country is for them to have mock parliamentary experience. I believe that in each State, in association with each State Parliament, there ought to be an annual parliament involving representative youth with an actual agenda and preliminary discussion and instruction about procedures such as standing orders and the conduct of an actual day's proceedings within the parliament. Linked with that, there should be some helpful information about the real Parliament, of which they would be the guests for that day or two. Then drawn from those assemblies around the States, there ought to be an annual exercise of that kind here in this Parliament. I commend it, and I think it is something that can flow from this inquiry.

Finally, I briefly refer to the importance of giving added emphasis to the time when a person is added to the Australian electoral roll. We have citizenship ceremonies for those who come as migrants to this country. They are high occasions of enormous importance to the individual-not quite as important perhaps as the marriage ceremony but, nevertheless, a very important ceremony. We do not have anything when someone is added to the electoral roll, and I believe that consideration should be given to that.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

You have also raised the matter of establishing a continuing base level of outlays for the Parliamentary Departments. I shall write to you on this matter after I have had the opportunity to consult with Madam Speaker.

The golden thread that runs through this correspondence and all other correspondence with the Minister for Finance is that the level of funding which is provided by Senator Walsh is less than adequate. As I have said previously, there is a fundamental distinction to be drawn between funding considerations in respect of government departments and the Parliament. The truth is that, the larger the bureaucracy gets, the greater the amount of legislation and the greater the amount of activity generated in the Parliament by the Government, so that the funding levels required by the Parliament are bound to go up. On the one hand we have the Government increasing the workload and responsibility of the Parliament, at least its functional responsibility, but at the same time significantly reducing the capacity of the Parliament to fulfil its obligations.

The Government looks aghast at the fact that there has been a significant increase in the cost of the functioning of Parliament, having moved as we did after 60 years from the provisional Parliament House to the permanent Parliament House. Even blind Freddy or a drover's dog would understand that the difference between this building and the 1927 building was bound to have caused dramatic increases in expenditure. There are 6,000 pass holders alone in this building, but the Government is shocked to see that outlays for the purpose of the parliamentary departments has gone up. Yet, in its own narrow, parochial, perverted and sectional way, this Government is prepared to allow outlays for its own purposes, its own benefits and its own functioning as a government to go up while those of the Parliament as a whole go down. This is best demonstrated when one looks across the corridor to the Executive wing of this building. But an arm and a limb of the functioning of this Parliament, the ministerial wing is not satisfied simply to have security attendants to protect and service it and fulfil its obligations in the same way as do the attendants who look after the daily needs of other members of parliament. TALK.START.PARA: —They need to be in permanent care, basically.

—It has been put to me by Senator Stone that they need to be in permanent care, not just day care. Perhaps that is the problem. But it is costing taxpayers $5m. The Ministers having established that they need that protection-probably from themselves more than from the public-the security officers are not prepared to carry messages, they are not prepared to shuffle paper, they are not prepared to fulfil the obligations of the ordinary attendants. That is a job for somebody else. Their job is to stroll up and down with their hands behind their backs, their noses in the air and their eyes in every direction protecting these people from the poor peasants they imagine are going to break down the door at any time to attack them. I am glad to say that the Senate Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing to the best of my knowledge is still examining the responsibilities of these Protective Service officers to see why they cannot do the duties that are done by attendants in the other parts of the building.

SPEECH.PARA: If we look at the use of VIP aircraft and other services available to the Government, do we see any cutbacks? No, we see none. SPEECH.PARA: We are now going to find ourselves in the situation of having more committee work and less funding. Senator Walsh tells us that these committees are an absolute waste of time in his view and ought by and large to be abolished. The tragedy is that this summarises the Government's disdain, contempt and disregard for the democratic process which is articulated and reflected in the parliamentary process. The Government sees itself as having a proprietary interest in the Parliament. It does not see itself as just part of the Parliament, making its contribution in the Parliament in the process of government; it sees the Parliament as its own. I say with respect that, sadly, the Government takes the same attitude to some of the committees of which I am a member that have responsibility for the functioning of the Parliament.
