I hope that in the future, with the support of the Australian Democrats and the independents, the Senate, if necessary, will reject the appropriations at the levels given to us by the Government and defer them until they provide the appropriate resources necessary for the proper, efficient and effective functioning of the Senate, allowing it to scrutinise government legislation in the way in which it was intended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating a number of Appropriation Bills which set aside certain amounts of money for the Government to give effect to its Budget and its ongoing expenses. In Australia recently we have witnessed an attitude of disconcertment with the direction being taken by this Federal Government and the suggestion that the whole economic direction needs to be turned around. We have recently seen the Tasmanian election, which resulted in a substantial number of independent green candidates gaining the balance of power in that Parliament. We have had spokespeople such as Professor David Suzuki addressing very large audiences in a number of States and pointing to the inability of the conventional economic model to address the very severe environmental problems which the world currently faces. He indicated that the direction in which we need to go is quite different from that in which this Government and most other governments in the Western world are going. David Suzuki was reflecting on a message which Paul Ehrlich has been giving to the world for quite a number of years.

SPEECH.PARA: In contrast, earlier today Senator Michael Baume pointed to the possibility of negative growth, something which David Suzuki has called a blessing and a requirement. Senator Michael Baume has said that if we go into negative growth we will really be going down the gurgler and that clearly we need to do certain things to stimulate economic growth because that is a sine qua non of a healthy society. The point of divergence between the Australian Democrats and both of the other parties is that we are not committed to that conventional view about economic growth. We are committed to the idea of a sustainable, steady, stable economy rather than continually attempting to make the economy grow. It is interesting to reflect on the fact that the word `economics' and the word `ecology' have the same origin. But over the years economics has moved away from ecology, and economists seem to have forgotten that the basis of economic activity is the natural environment. They seem to have adopted the view that economics can continue to promote growth without concern for the welfare of the natural environment on which it feeds. In the process, of course, economic growth is destroying the environment-it is destroying the very basis on which human life, all other life and economic activity ultimately depend.

A few days after the Tasmanian election, Mr Hawke said that within two to three months he would come out with the world's best environment policy. That caused me to write an open letter to him pointing out that if he were genuine about coming out with such a policy he would have to review seriously the whole economic model on which his policies, and those which the Opposition would impose on us, are based. I said that those policies would need to be reversed and that he would need to move away from growth economics towards sustainable economics. I invited Mr Hawke to openly debate that question with me. So far I have not had a reply.

There is a desperate need to bring economics and ecology together again. In this respect I find that there is no difference at all between the Labor and Liberal policies. Not many journalists seem to have picked this up. However, David Barnett did so in last week's Bulletin. He is one of the first to pick up that what the environmental movement, the green independents and the Democrats are on about is something which cannot be neatly slotted into the vectors on which the Labor and Liberal parties lie. We are really moving in quite a different direction, and the economic policies which we would put in place are quite different.

The Labor and Liberal policies are based on the concept that growth is both desirable and, to some extent, inevitable. They are also based on a belief that the market, the competitive system, will somehow serve the common good and that the free operation of that market will somehow produce a better condition for all who operate in it. We claim that that policy can solve neither the worsening social problems nor the problems of a deteriorating environment. The word `growth' is so loosely used by a number of economists and particularly by politicians that it is necessary to observe what it means. In this context it means growth of gross domestic product (GDP), growth in the dollar value of goods and services consumed year on year. In other words, this year we consumed more than we did last year; next year we will consume more again; and the year after that we will consume more again. This is normally measured as a percentage flow through the economy. There is a attempt to increase exponentially that flow through the economy.

As I have observed in the past, what has been attempted is an exponential increase in the throughput of resources in a finite world. That simply cannot be accepted as rational; it is to attempt the impossible. In pursuing these models, it follows that any measures that are made to save bits and pieces of the environment-and I stress this very much in the context of Mr Hawke's claim of developing the world's best environment policy-be they forests in Tasmania, heritage areas, wild rivers, clean air, clean water, or access to any natural environment at all, will only be temporary as long as governments attempt to make the economy grow. I say this for the simple reason that if we exponentially seek to increase the throughput of resources, sooner or later we will need to consume those very resources which we have set aside and which we hope to preserve in perpetuity.

So there is a fundamental conflict between our desire to look after the environment which, after all, is the only environment we have and probably the only environment we ever will have, and the use of the economic models on which this Government and this Opposition predicate their polities and on which these appropriations that we are looking at at the moment are fundamentally based.

Because of the very marked changes which are occurring in the environment, even those areas which have been set aside so as to protect natural species, short of being destroyed by demand on the resources, will, nonetheless, be destroyed by other elements in the growth economy. The consumption of a wide range of resources is changing the composition of the atmosphere which will mean that all those areas that we have sought to protect because of their unique species, ecologies and habitats, will simply be in the wrong place. Over the next half century or so, we face, quite literally, massive species extinctions as a consequence of the pursuit of economic growth.

There are a number of defects in the model which need to be pointed out if we are to put in its place a different model, if we are seriously attempting to put in place a model of sustainability. For the reason that we are living in a society which is predicated very heavily on economic indicators and measures, we need to use economic tools. Therefore, we need to get the economic indicators right so that they will point us in the right direction.

It is necessary to observe that GDP, which is so vaunted by economists and a number of people who speak loosely in this place about economic growth, measures as benefits the things which ordinary people, and certainly most ecologists and environmentalists, would regard as costs. This is where the concerns about the environment and the solution to the environmental problems meet fairly and squarely the concerns which ordinary everyday people have in regard to the cost of housing, the cost of providing all those goods and services which they regard as essential for a quality life and which, if denied, will lead to a deterioration in their lives.

Over the last year or so I have asked a number of questions in this place, principally of Senator Peter Walsh, in relation to this principal defect in the measure of economic growth. I remind the Senate that on one occasion I asked him a question about the $5.7 billion a year that we have to spend as a result of motor vehicle accidents. I asked where that amount appeared in the gross domestic product. Did it appear as an addition? Senator Walsh agreed that it did appear as an addition. After a bit of obfuscation, he concluded his remarks by saying:

. . . to exclude medical costs borne by households would require more fundamental changes to the accounts-indeed, to the extent where it could touch off a spiral in which all of the gross domestic product gradually disappeared.

What those words indicate is that, if we were to start seriously to take out of gross domestic product those things that every normal, rational person recognised as a cost, the gross domestic product might largely, or totally, disappear. That is the point at which people must recognise the link between the fallacies in the economic modelling and what they perceive as being wrong in their ordinary, everyday lives.

The population of this country is slightly over 16 million. Mr Hawke is on record as having said recently that he would like to see the population increase to 20 million by the year 2000-an increase of 25 per cent in 10 years. As I pointed out previously, 80 per cent of the increase in Australia's population over the last 40 years has accrued in capital cities. What Mr Hawke is attempting is essentially to add an Adelaide to a Sydney within 10 years. It is not surprising that Mr Bob Carr, the Leader of the Opposition in New South Wales, has said that Sydney should put up a `house full' sign. Clearly that imposition on an already large and bulging city would produce enormous tensions.

The economy certainly would grow as a consequence. The costs of providing roads, sewers, electricity, education, law facilities, water, telephones, et cetera, would appear as additions to gross domestic product. It costs a great deal more to put people on the periphery of an already large city. People have to travel further to work. They see those things as costs. They have to spend more on petrol and on vehicle insurance and registration. Then there is the likelihood of accidents, as well as the cost of medical care and vehicle repair. People see all those things as costs, yet they go down as additions to the gross domestic product.

It may well be that the costs of growth have exceeded the benefits. That is why we are deceiving ourselves as a country and as a people-a people becoming poorer, not richer. It is also the reason for this paradox of the apparent conflict between what ordinary people perceive as a worsening quality of life and what economists and the Government say about growth in the economy. Precisely because of those measures that are used to put costs down as benefits, what ordinary, everyday people see as a deterioration can be measured by the Government as a benefit.

Moreover, this Government's acceptance of the naked operation of a market system ensures that the cost of housing and all those other facilities that city dwellers need escalates. Because money is treated as a marketable commodity, the interest rates that people have to pay also increase. That is the point at which there are clear parallels between what is wrong with our environment and what is wrong with the economy which impacts on people in their ordinary, everyday lives.

Secondly, gross domestic product, which is the main indicator of the health, or otherwise, of the economy, is a measure of flow through the economy. Unlike private companies, we do not keep the equivalent of a capital account. There is no national capital account. We do not put any value on trees in situ; we do not put any value on forests before they are cut down. We do not put value on iron ore or lead or copper or zinc in the ground; we give it value only as we take it out. When we do that we are simply liquefying an asset. We are taking it out of the capital account, which we do not keep, and putting it into the cash flow account. Private companies do not do that. Every accountant will tell us that a company could not be run in that way, yet we attempt to run the whole country like that. As Senator Sheil has just pointed out, that is liquidation. We are indeed behaving as though we were a company in liquidation: we are liquefying our assets. That is what is going on, and that is the other thing which gives the lie to this economic process and indicates the direction in which we need to move.

TALK.START.PARA: —Anyone who uses capital items is in liquidation. Is that what you are saying?

—No. What I am saying is that a company keeps a capital account. As assets are used up they are depreciated, and money is put back into the capital account. We recognise that there is a capital account. However, a country does not keep the equivalent of a national capital account. We do not have a capital account nationally.
—Aren't we cashing in the capital item?

—We are cashing in the capital item, but we are not replacing it, as a company would do. There is no depreciation allowance against forest destruction. The consequence of both these defects in the growth model is that no value whatsoever is put on those things that nature provides free-clean air, clean water, access to nature, and so on. But as we destroy those things and spend money to replace them, that money goes down as an addition to gross domestic product. Therefore, by destroying those things, we appear to become better off. It really is a crazy system, and it needs to be turned around. Down the growth road there is no solution either to the very significant social and economic problems that face this country or to the very significant environmental problems facing both this country and the rest of the world. We must turn the model round.

SPEECH.PARA: Economists use arguments such as `Growth allows us to spend more on looking after the environment'. One has only to observe that what we spend on attempting to repair the environment goes down as an addition to gross domestic product to realise the complete fallacy in that argument. In other words, if we spend more on repairing the damage that we have caused, our gross domestic product grows. If the argument were valid, we could spend more on looking after the environment, and that money also would go down as an addition to GDP. Thus, we would become richer and richer as we repaired the environment, and could spend more and more. Of course, it is a ridiculous argument. What it does is count a cost-the cost of repairing the environment-as a benefit, and and so we think that we can spend it twice or thrice over. As a country-indeed, as a world-we must adopt a sustainable, steady state economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why does it have to be a steady state? If it is a state, can it not be an expanding one?
—Equilibrium is not static, is it?

—Clearly these honourable senators do not understand what a steady state is. A steady state can be a dynamic steady state, one in which there is a flow through the economy, but one in which the inputs and the outputs remain stable. It is qualified by the words `sustainable steady' state. If one imagines that one has a large container of water with a tap pouring water into it and a hole in the bottom of the container, provided the inflow and the outflow are the same the level of water in the container will remain static, but there will be a continuous flow through that container. That is a steady state condition. If one likens that to population, one could have a large input, a large output or the same population-equivalent to a high birth rate, a high death rate and a very short life. One could keep the same level of population by having a very small input and a very small output, which would correspond with a very small birth rate, a small death rate and longevity. I suggest that that latter state is more desirable.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to resources we need to maintain a throughput in the economy sufficient to maintain a stock of items which we need for a reasonable quality of life. That stock is obtained by minimising the throughput of resources, not by maximising it, which means attempting to minimise the gross domestic product for the maintenance of that stock. It is the stock that we should value-the stock which at the moment we do not even measure. We should not simply attempt endlessly to increase the throughput of resources, be they material resources or human labour. It makes no sense to increase the throughput of human labour, either.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do Third World countries get on?
—Is any net increase in population a bad theory?
—Sit under a palm tree and eat coconuts?

—Clearly, these ideas are quite novel to many honourable senators in this place. I think it has been extremely useful to raise these issues because it seems that they are hearing them for the first time. I may be playing a useful educational role. There is a vast amount of literature on this subject.
—It is unworkable.

—Senator McGauran says that it is unworkable. I point out to him that we are rapidly destroying this planet at an incredible rate. The economy is not producing the welfare that people are looking for. The present economy is failing. It is not for me to establish that what I am saying is workable in Senator McGauran's eyes because Senator McGauran clearly believes the present system is producing the goods when clearly it is not. He has not even opened his eyes to see what is happening around him.

SPEECH.PARA: In order to move in this direction, as I have already indicated, because we live in a society which is predicated on economic matters and because it takes account of these economic matters, it is necessary to use economic levers, to establish a number of different economic indicators and to establish qualifiers in those indicators that we already have. It is necessary that we establish a national capital account and that we give value to those resources in situ which we are progressively, as the honourable senator on my right indicated a minute ago, liquidating. When we take resources out of the ground and export them overseas without any value added component, we are simply shifting money from the capital account to the cash flow account. We are not becoming richer. This generation may have generated some cash flow; future generations will be poorer because those resources have been liquidated.

To draw a parallel, Amory Lovins, an American writer of considerable note who is perhaps not known in this chamber, some years ago remarked, `Whoever heard of developing a bank account by taking money out of it?'. That is precisely what we are doing with our resources. We need to establish a national capital account and to modify very heavily the gross domestic product measure. We need to take the costs out of gross domestic product, put the costs down as costs and the benefits down as benefits. When we do that we might see that the costs of growth are now outweighing the benefits. That would demonstrate to people why they sense they are becoming, and are indeed, poorer. Finally, we need to put beside those measures independent non-economic measures of real human welfare, such as health, morbidity and literacy measures. We need to measure suicide and nutrition rates, access to and quality of education in our society, access to natural areas and per capita pollution. These are all things which could be measured and, when put beside those economic indicators, give us a much better indication of whether society is becoming better off in a broad sense rather than in the very narrow sense in which we now believe we are becoming better off-a simple increase in GDP.

We need to change direction from mindlessly pursuing growth for growth's sake-a direction which is destroying the environment on which the economy ultimately depends and on which we, as human beings, and all other life on this planet ultimately depend-to a direction which is sustainable in the long run. Nothing short of this fundamental change will ensure that the environment will remain for our children and our children's children. There are very severe problems which most people perceive in their ordinary everyday lives, and there are very severe environmental problems. Those two sets of problems which appear so disparate have exactly the same common cause-the pursuit of growth. That is something that the Government and the Opposition share. It is something which divides the economic policies of the Democrats from the policies of those two parties.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with the previous speaker, Senator Coulter, that the growth economy is unsustainable in the long run. The message of sustainability is the single most important message for governments everywhere to understand. A paradigm shift is taking place globally. A redirection is urgently needed. Regrettably, politicians, political parties and governments are often slow to respond to the challenging changes that are required if we are not to damage our environment beyond the point of being able to cope with the exploitative demands made on it. The Earthcare test needs to be applied to our management of resources and to industrial projects-in fact, to our whole lifestyle. Will people in 50, 100 or 200 years look back at the projects which are getting the go ahead now and ask, `How could this have been allowed'? We are already saying that about many projects which were planned far more recently than 100 or 200 years ago. We need to look into the future and consider the sustainability of what we are allowing.

SPEECH.PARA: Following the recent electoral victory of green independents in Tasmania-I think this must be seen as an irrefutable indicator of the new direction demanded by informed citizens-Senator Richardson made this great observation:
Because we've done so much to stuff up our world in the past 200 years, the cost of cleaning it up is so great that even the economic argument is becoming environmental.

I would add that the cost of clean-up and a sustainable investment towards the prevention of further stuff-ups must be reflected in Budget appropriations. An environmentally sound energy strategy is an obvious prerequisite to a sustainable society, an aim which has been endorsed by conservationists, governments and industry alike in the national conservation strategy. How we fuel our growth is central to many of the environmental problems and costs we are faced with. The accelerating greenhouse effect is a case in point. In a nutshell, the Government has failed to allocate the necessary funds to the types of research and development which are most likely to contribute to reducing the environmental costs of development; that is, increased energy efficiency and a transition to renewable energy systems. For example, the Commonwealth energy management program has been scrapped, even though the up-front cost of most of the projects facilitated by it were recouped within three years. We have lost an avenue of active promotion of appropriate energy use in favour of a market approach.

A study carried out at the Harvard Business School some ten years ago found that, for renewable energy systems to get a fair go in the market place, two-thirds of their supply cost should be subsidised to overcome the years of subsidy accumulated by conventional energy systems. Judging by the ongoing bias in the Government's Budget towards fossil fuel research and development, the subsidy owing to clean energy in Australia would have to be much more than that. Yet, I am told by those scientists still waiting that the first round of the Government's $1m per annum grants for renewable energy research, known as the Sunshine Fund, still has not been awarded, even though the next round of applications for them is closing.

Of major concern to many scientists involved in energy research is the lack of support for an extension service for promoting the proven technologies. While the importance of extension services has long been recognised in the area of primary industry, the funds are consistently denied to the renewable energy and energy efficiency sectors. There is a critical need for an ongoing formal link between the suppliers, the people on the land, industry, educators and, last but not least, politicians, to promote the application of current knowledge and technology to current needs. Without this liaison, or extension service, all the primary research in the world will not save us.

In a similar vein, while it is important to contribute to worldwide monitoring of atmospheric changes in order to understand the greenhouse effect, immediate returns in terms of reducing the pollution build-up are possible only from investing in energy efficiency, the adoption of solar and other clean energy sources, and the implementation of much higher pollution standards. A 20 per cent reduction of carbon dioxide emissions by the year 2000 is possible only if an investment is made now. This is not reflected in the appropriations. New directions in energy and environmental protection policy will incur costs to specific industry sectors in the short term but must be addressed. For example, the phasing out of chlorofluorocarbons by the year 2000 has now gained international support. A total phase-out of ozone-depleting substances is necessary to prevent much greater costs to human health, our food supply and the natural environment in the very near future. Yet the Government is dragging its feet in order not to offend industry. The cost of such consideration for the producers will begin to show up in melanomas and other fatal cancers in the years to come.

In regard to the Australian Labor Party's policy platform, clause 79 and the need to implement immediate efforts to increase energy efficiency in buildings, why is the public sector not setting the example? A mere 2 to 3 per cent added to current capital outlays, with a specific requirement for energy efficiency standards to be built into new works, would contribute substantially to this goal and deliver tangible returns in energy savings almost immediately. Other projects which in themselves do not amount to major diversions of funds, but represent the very important changes in direction required to avoid the stuff-ups referred to by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson), are consistently denied the resources needed to function. The multi-disciplinary research and analysis carried out by the Centre for Resource and Environmental Studies of the Australian National University in its fundamental questions program operates on a shoestring budget. This program brings the sciences and humanities together to tackle the very questions that governments are at pains to avoid. Support of such intelligent problem solving could provide the needed answers for how to achieve the change in economic direction, which we all know will result from the growing concern about our environment and quality of life.

Another example of an excellent community initiative ignored in Government appropriations is the Wisenet science shop which aims to coordinate scientific expertise with community needs. It is a response from women within the scientific community to redirect science research to serve the community. It operated on $15,000 raised totally by voluntary labour last year, and was not even granted a hearing with the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business, Mr Jones, before being refused any assistance in the wake of government funding. Without a paid coordinator, this opportunity to take science to the people will be lost-such a small investment with enormous potential for reducing the `stuff-up factor'.

Other direct costs of ignoring our impacts on the environment include the loss forever of many species of indigenous flora and fauna, and soil degradation. It is estimated that since European settlement 18 species of mammal have become extinct, representing two-thirds of all the mammal species that have become extinct worldwide in historical times. At least 129 species of vascular plants have also become extinct, most disappearing with clearing for farms. The processes of extinction continue, with a further 40 mammal species and 209 vascular plant species currently endangered. In 1987, election promises were made by the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, and the then Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, Mr Cohen, to establish an endangered species unit within the Australian National Parks Service. Only in October 1988 was an advisory committee established, and no estimates which would allow the establishment of an endangered species unit are included in the appropriation Bills under scrutiny at the moment. That is a great oversight on the part of the Government not only for unique species facing imminent extermination but also for the Government's own survival.

According to the advisory committee, for just $2m research and survey work could be initiated, a nationally networked database on endangered species could be established, an education and publicity program could be launched, and a national network of non-government organisations involved with endangered species and an endangered species unit could be established-one of the many cheap but effective public commitments to sustainability available to but resisted by the Government. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support, upon notice, on 7 December 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) On how many occasions since July 1988 has the radar at Tullamarine Airport in Melbourne been inoperative.
(2) What is the maximum delay which has been caused to movements of aircraft as a result of any malfunctioning or breakdown of radar equipment.
(3) What steps, if any, are being taken to rectify any problems with radar equipment at Tullamarine Airport.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Since July 1988 there have been three occasions.

The first was on 19 November 1988 when there was a power failure which lasted from 6.30 p.m. to 8.15 p.m. and the route surveillance radar was stopped but radar services were still provided within 80 nautical miles of Melbourne airport using the Terminal Area Radar.

The second occurrence was on 27 January 1989 when there were three unconnected failures with total time lost being 7 hours and 11 minutes. Again services continued inside 80 nautical miles using the Terminal Area Radar.

The third occasion was on 2 May 1989 when there was a power failure from 11.45 a.m. to 12.05 p.m. Restoration of the radar display systems was immediately undertaken, with the first displays being restored in 10 minutes and full service restored within 20 minutes. Air traffic controllers reverted to procedural control of aircraft during the 20 minute period.
(2) Records of delays are not kept.
(3) A radar rehabilitation project has been set up to rectify identified problems and has already resulted in a number of changes, particularly in the software being used.

There was an additional radar antenna installed on the Terminal Area Radar in April accompanied by more detailed changes to the computer software being used. The software changes will simplify controller keyboard functions, allow expansion in Display Unit memory and rectify faults in processing equipment.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 19 December 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: Which areas have been excluded from receiving parliamentary broadcasts under the new Public Broadcasting Service and what percentage of the previous listening audience has now been omitted from receiving the signal.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question, based in part on information provided by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation:

ANSWER.PARA: Under the Parliamentary Proceedings Broadcasting Act 1946, the ABC must broadcast the proceedings of the House of Representatives or the Senate or of joint sittings in the six State capitals and Newcastle, and from any other station prescribed by regulation (currently a Canberra station is so prescribed.) The coverage of both the interim and the permanent parliamentary networks fulfill the legal requirements imposed on the ABC by the Act.

Audience research has indicated that approximately 6% of listeners in metropolitan centres listen to Radio National. Research has also indicated that the broadcasting of Parliamentary proceedings has not increased the number of Radio National listeners. Based on that total population figure, the number of potential Radio National listeners who will be outside the range of the new Parliamentary broadcasts is estimated to be 50,000 Australia-wide. However, only a small proportion of these Radio National listeners would be Parliamentary broadcasting listeners.

The following population centres, which were able to pick up Parliamentary broadcasts under previous transmitting arrangements, may no longer receive them on the interim network introduced on ABC stand-by transmitters (ie 2PB Sydney, Canberra and Newcastle, 3PB Melbourne; 4PB Brisbane; 5PB Adelaide, 6PB Perth and 7PB Hobart).
New South Wales-Nowra, Bomaderry, Jervis Bay, Bundanoon, Lithgow, Wallerawang.
Queensland-Beaudesert, Rosewood, Laidley, Gatton, Woodford, Lowood.
South Australia-Port Augusta, Whyalla, Port Lincoln, Port Pirie.
Victoria-Warrnambool, Portland, Hamilton, Ararat, Maryborough, Bendigo, Stawell, Horsham, Shepparton, Echuca, Swan Hill, Deniliquin, Warragul, Traralgon, Moe, Sale, Wangaratta.

It is important to recognise that most of the people living in these areas would have received a marginal or poor grade of service under the previous transmission arrangements. In most cases the broadcast signal would not have met the Department of Transport and Communications' Planning Guidelines for an adequate service.

However, there is still a significant degree of fortuitous reception of transmissions on the stand-by network in regional areas, particularly in South Australia. Reception in and around Perth is actually an improvement on the Radio National transmissions.

The Parliamentary network will transfer to new frequencies on a permanent basis in the context of the AM/FM conversion plan in the mainland state capital cities. This will occur in Sydney, Perth and Adelaide later this year, and in Brisbane, and Melbourne in 1991 and 1992 respectively. Canberra, Hobart and Newcastle will need to be considered separately in the context of AM/FM conversion policy in multi-station regional markets.
The transfer of Parliamentary Broadcasts to the interim network and later to the permanent network was approved by the Joint Committee on Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 1 March 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Attorney-General aware of an article which appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald on Wednesday 17 August 1988 entitled `It's the box that watches you while you watch the box' and which said in part:

``The smart probe is the main difference between the two systems. With it, McNair should be able to `fingerprint' each videotape at the start of recording, enabling it to tell not only what was recorded (by channel, date and time), but also when-and if-it is ever played back.''

(2) Is it possible that any such information, or evidence collected by McNair Anderson, about the videotaping of copyrighted television programmes may be used in court against infringements of copyright laws; if so, will the Attorney-General act to prevent the possibility of any such prosecution arising?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) Whether and, if so, to what extent information collected by a surveying organisation concerning the videotaping of television programs by survey participants could be used in court proceedings would depend upon the admissability of that information under the applicable rules of evidence. As participants in surveys are understood to participate on a voluntary basis, they would have a full opportunity to negotiate with the surveying organisation regarding the scope of the information to be collected from them and the use to which such information, or any part of it, might or might not be put by that organisation. Moreover, the making of a copy of a television program without the permission of the holder of a copyright in the program is an offence under the Copyright Act only if done for sale or hire of the copy so made. As most home videotaping is presumably undertaken for later viewing in the home or other social context, the possibility of prosecution would be unlikely to arise.
I see no reason, therefore, to intervene in the manner suggested by the Honourable Senator's question.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 26 April 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Given the Minister for Education's assurance of 15 November 1988 to the Ethnic Schools Association of South Australia to keep a review of the Commonwealth Schools Program under consideration, will he now undertake a full review of the program in the 1988-89 financial year; if not, why not; if so, when will the review commence and how long will it take.

(2) Is the Minister aware of the November 1984 study commissioned by the Commonwealth Schools Commission which states that: `Members of Ethnic Communities not involved in insertion class programs are concerned that a very substantial and rapidly increasing proportion of the money distributed through the Ethnic Schools program bears no relationship to the primary aims of that program'; if not, why not; if so, what is the Government doing to alleviate these concerns of ethnic communities.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) It is not considered appropriate to undertake a formal review of the Ethnic Schools Program at present since issues such as the relationship of ethnic school after-hours classes, ethnic school insertion classes, and regular school language classes impinge directly upon recently introduced programs under the Government's National Policy on Languages. It would be premature to review the Ethnic Schools Program prior to the impact of these new programs being fully assessed. These views were conveyed to the Ethnic Schools Association of South Australia on 12 December 1988.
(2) I am aware of the study referred to. The Ethnic Schools Program has two objectives:
to maintain relevant languages and cultures among students of non-English speaking background, and
to increase the awareness and understanding for all children of the different community languages and cultures within Australian society.

To the extent that both after-hours and insertion classes meet either of these objectives, they have a legitimate right to funding under current guidelines and the concerns of the 138,000 students now in insertion classes must be given due weight against those in after-hours classes. It should be noted that following the decision to apply a ceiling on funding to ethnic schools authorities at 1986 levels, organisations operating either after-hours or insertion classes cannot claim for additional enrolments.
